revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Harry J. W. Belvin | image = [[File:Choctaw Chief Harry J. W. Belvin.jpg|200px]] | image_size = | caption = | office = Chief of the [[Choctaw Nation|Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma]] | term_start = 1948 | term_end = 1975 | birth_date = December 11, 1900 | birth_place = [[Boswell, Oklahoma|Boswell]], [[Choctaw Nation]], [[Indian Territory]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = September 19, 1986 (aged 85) | death_place = [[Durant, Oklahoma|Durant]], [[Oklahoma]], [[United States|U.S.]] | predecessor = [[William A. Durant]] | successor = C. David Gardner | office2 = Member of the [[Oklahoma Senate]] from the 20th District | term_start2 = 1961 | term_end2 = 1965 | predecessor2 = Keith Cartwright | successor2 = Roy Grantham | office3 = Member of the [[Oklahoma House of Representatives]] from the 20th District | term_start3 = 1955 | term_end3 = 1961 | predecessor3 = James E. Douglas | successor3 = Sam Sullivan | native_name = | nicknames = | known_for = | death_cause = | resting_place = Highland Cemetery, Durant, Oklahoma | rp_coordinates = | religion = Presbyterian Christian | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] | education = [[Southeastern Oklahoma State University]] | spouse = Lucille Brightwell {{small|(1903-1991)}} | children = Louise Belvin Frazier | parents = | relations = | signature = | footnotes = }}
'''Harry James Watson "Jimmy" Belvin''' (1900 -1986) was an educator and served as an [[Oklahoma]] State Representative and Senator. He was the first elected principal chief of any of the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] in the 20th century, and the longest serving principal chief of the [[Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma]]. He saw his tribe through termination, restoration, and a rebirth of Native Pride. He was a polarizing leader, seen by some as a semi-dictator who held onto the office of principal chief and used his power to advocate for complete assimilation into the dominant society, suppressing Choctaw traditions, language and ceremonial practices as undesirable remnants of an unrefined history.<ref name="Akers (2013)">{{cite book|last1=Akers|first1=Donna L.|title=Culture and customs of the Choctaw indians|date=2013|publisher=Greenwood|location=Santa Barbara|isbn=978-0-313-36401-3|page=153|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XeDeGlxgASUC&lpg|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> To others, he was a well-liked, populist leader, who went door-to-door talking with tribe members, informing them on issues, and trying to develop the means the alleviate the poverty and unemployment they faced.<ref name="Lambert AIQ Vol. 31" />
==Early life== Jimmy Belvin was born in [[Boswell, Oklahoma|Boswell]]<ref name="Lambert (2007)">{{cite book|last1=Lambert|first1=Valerie|title=Choctaw nation : a story of American Indian resurgence|date=2007|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln|isbn=978-0-8032-1105-6|page=73|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x-xQwztsSaQC&lpg|accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref> Choctaw County, [[Indian Territory]] on December 11, 1900<ref name="Obituary - Oklahoman">{{cite news|title=Longtime Chief of Choctaw Nation Dies in Durant|url=http://newsok.com/longtime-chief-of-choctaw-nation-dies-in-durant/article/2160416|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=The Oklahoman|date=September 21, 1986}}</ref> to Watson J. and Mabel Powers Belvin. He was a direct descendant of the original Belvins who were forced over the [[Trail of Tears]] from Mississippi to Indian Territory.<ref name="ParisTX (1957)">{{cite news|title=Boswell's Homecoming Also Statehood Event Oklahoma News Bureau BOSWELL, Okla|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/5869903/|accessdate=7 January 2015|publisher=The Paris News|date=May 31, 1957|location=Paris, Texas|page=12}}</ref> He attended school in Boswell and graduated from Southeastern Teachers College with a Bachelor of Science degree,<ref name="Choctaw chief list">{{cite web|title=Harry J. W. Belvin 1948 - 1975|url=http://www.choctawnation.com/history/people/chiefs/1948---harry-j-w-belvin/|website=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma|accessdate=6 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720034117/http://www.choctawnation.com/history/people/chiefs/1948---harry-j-w-belvin/|archivedate=20 July 2011|df=}}</ref> going on to earn a Master's of Education at the University of Oklahoma which he completed in 1941.<ref name="OU Roll Call (1941)">{{cite web|title=OU Roll Call|url=http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/sooner/articles/p18%2C20%2C22-32_1941v14n1_OCR.pdf|publisher=University of Oklahoma Sooner Magazine|accessdate=7 January 2015|page=18|date=September 1941}}</ref>
Belvin taught school at Mayhew,<ref name="ParisTX (1957)" /> Bryan County and in Choctaw County from 1923 until 1939.<ref name="Durant obit">{{cite news|title=Chief Harry James "Jimmy" Watson Belvin|url=http://www.okgenweb.org/~okchocta/obits/26/belvin_james_watson.htm|accessdate=10 January 2015|publisher=Durant Daily Democrat|date=21 September 1986}}</ref> In 1941 he was elected Bryan County Superintendent of Public Instruction, a position he held until 1952.<ref name="Choctaw chief list" /> He then began operating a Hereford cattle ranch in Bryan and Choctaw counties.<ref name="Miami (1961)">{{cite news|title='Chief Not Just a Nickname For Senator Belvin of Durant'|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/30431777/|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=Miami Daily News-Record|date=July 30, 1961|location=Miami, Oklahoma|page=15}}</ref>
After his first successful election to the Oklahoma legislature in 1955, Belvin served three terms in the Oklahoma State House of Representatives representing Bryan County. In 1960, he was elected as an Oklahoma State Senator.<ref name="Miami (1961)" />
==Coal and Asphalt Lands== As early as 1946, support for Belvin becoming principal chief had been growing.<ref name="Chickasaw Nation">{{cite web|title=Jimmy Belvin and the Rise of Tribal Sovereignty, 1944-48|url=https://www.chickasaw.net/Our-Nation/History/Historical-Articles/History/Indian-Territory/Jimmy-Belvin-and-the-Rise-of-Tribal-Sovereignty,-1.aspx|publisher=The Chickasaw Nation|accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref> [[William A. Durant]] had served since 1937,<ref name="Chief Durant">{{cite web|title=William Durant 1937 - 1948|url=http://www.choctawnation.com/history/people/chiefs/1937---william-durant/|publisher=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma|accessdate=6 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128113610/http://www.choctawnation.com/history/people/chiefs/1937---william-durant/#|archive-date=2015-01-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and was seen as having made little headway on selling the asphalt lands of the Choctaw and Chickasaw. At issue were some {{convert|400000|acres|km2}} of lands that were jointly owned by the Choctaw and Chickasaw tribes. Based on a 1902 agreement, the US had agreed to purchase these lands within three years, but had still not done so. In 1946, Chief Durant and Chickasaw Governor [[Floyd Maytubby]] were asking for $33.1 million which the US government valued at $2.2 million. Belvin was, on the other hand was seen as an educated, galvanized leader who wanted to revitalize the tribe. Even before he was chief, he wrote long letters to Congressman [[Carl Albert]], Congressman [[William Stigler]], Senator [[Elmer Thomas]], Senator [[Edward H. Moore]], the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] office, and the Superintendent of the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] criticizing the delays in finalizing the purchase.<ref name="Chickasaw Nation" />
When a settlement was finally reached of $8.5 million, Belvin again launched a letter-writing campaign questioning why the settlement was reached without allowing representatives of the Choctaw-Chickasaw Confederation to attend the negotiations.<ref name="Chickasaw Nation" /> Considering that the land contained 770 million tons of readily available coal, another 1 billion tons of reserve coal and asphalt, and was near a recent oil strike,<ref name="Truman">{{cite web|title=President Truman receives prominent Oklahoma Native American leaders in the Oval Office|url=http://www.historyinink.com/1317001_Truman_SP_with_Indian_leaders.htm|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> Belvin questioned how the coal could be valued at 1 cent per ton and the reserve coal, valued at 0.1 cent per ton.<ref name="Chickasaw Nation"/> Belvin was also highly critical of the fact that Chief Durant had not attended the negotiations, leaving the decision of "the most momentous meeting affecting the tribe's welfare since the [[Atoka Agreement]] of 1897" up to Maytubby and the Choctaw Tribal attorney.<ref name= "Truman"/>
Choctaw-Chickasaw Confederation was officially created on 9 January 1947,<ref name="C-C Confederation">{{cite web|title=Choctaw Chickasaw Confederation|url=http://oklahomafirms.us/choctaw-chickasaw-confederation.106999.company#top_info|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> though it had operated for several years, as a means for the tribes to track tribal assets, hold meetings and discussions and disseminate information outside of the "official" BIA structure.<ref name=Ardmoreite>{{cite news|title=Indians to Hold Meet at Antlers|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/us/oklahoma/ardmore/ardmore-daily-ardmoreite/1947/08-27/page-7|accessdate=10 January 2015|publisher=Ardmore Daily Ardmoreite|date=27 August 1947|location=Ardmore, Oklahoma|page=7}}</ref> After the sale had been negotiated, Belvin wrote letters as president of the Confederation to tribal members and urged them to attend informational meetings and decide whether or not they wanted to accept the offer. He did not give his own opinions, but urged each tribemember to vote according to their own conscience.<ref name="Indian Friend">{{cite web|title=Dear Indian Friend Letter|url=http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/utils/getfile/collection/gmccurtain/id/539/filename/540.pdf|website=University of Oklahoma|accessdate=10 January 2015|date=7 November 1947}}</ref> Though he thought the settlement amount was undervalued, once he became chief, Belvin stopped criticizing the amount and strove to collect the distribution so desperately needed by his poverty stricken tribe members.<ref name="Chickasaw Nation" />
==Choctaw Principal Chief== Belvin was first elected as Principal Chief of the Choctaw Nation in 1948.<ref name="Paris News (1948)">{{cite news|title=Belvin Reported Vote Leader In Race for Choctaw Chief|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/14096657/|accessdate=10 January 2015|publisher=The Paris News|date=27 June 1948|location=Paris, Texas|page=5}}</ref><ref name="10 Nov. 1954 BIA letter">{{cite web|title=Belvin Appointed Principal Chief of Oklahoma Choctaws|url=http://www.bia.gov/cs/groups/public/documents/text/idc016228.pdf|publisher=Department of the Interior|accessdate=7 January 2015|date=10 November 1954}}</ref> In fact, he was the first elected chief of any of the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] and of the Choctaw Nation in the 20th century. All chiefs of the Five Civilized Tribes of Oklahoma since the implementation of the [[Dawes Act]] had been appointed by the president upon recommendation from the BIA. Until the 1970s, the only two exceptions to presidential appointment were that in 1948 and again in 1954, the Choctaw were allowed to elect their chief. Both times, they elected Belvin,<ref name="Lambert 2007, p 66">Lambert (2007), p 66</ref> though voting was limited to a fraction of the eligible enrollees.<ref name= "Civ-05-01524-W">{{cite web|title=THE CHICKASAW NATION and THE CHOCTAW NATION v. THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR|url=http://www.msaj.com/~trustfund/Chickasaw%20OkWD%20Second%20Amended%20Complaint%206_19_09.pdf|website=Morisset Schlosser Jozwiak & Somerville|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref>
In the lead up to the 1954 election, the Department of the Interior informed Belvin that they did not believe the tribe warranted a full-time chief. Belvin contacted Congressman Carl Albert, also a proponent of tribal democracy, who worked behind the scenes to keep the Choctaw Principal Chief as a full-time position. Belvin believed so strongly in the right of the tribes to elect their own governance, that he persuaded the Chickasaw to press for their own elections.<ref name="Chickasaw Times">{{cite web|title=Historic 1959 Tribal Meeting at Ada's Aldridge Hotel|url=http://digital.turn-page.com/i/24128/34|website=Chickasaw Times|accessdate=8 January 2015|page=35|date=September 2007}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Though the Chickasaw tried for many years to convince the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] to allow them to vote on their own leadership, their requests were ignored.<ref name=Civ-05-01524-W />
===Inter-Tribal Council of the Five Civilized Tribes=== There had been several joint relationships among the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] throughout their history—the 1842 Inter-Tribal Council of the Deep Fork River, the 1861 United Nations of Indian Territory, and the 1866 Okmulgee Council.<ref name="Intertribal Council">{{cite web|title=Inter-Tribal Council of the Five Civilized Tribes|url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/I/IN033.html|website=digital.library.okstate|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref> Because of their similar histories and situations in Oklahoma, with removal, allotment, and government oversight, there was a recognition that tribal goals for development, education, services for tribe members, health initiatives and poverty alleviation were virtually the same and working together would be of benefit.<ref name="ITC History">{{cite web|title=Section One: Preserving Indian Heritage|url=http://www.fivecivilizedtribes.org/Home/History/ChapterFive.aspx|website=ITC 5 Civilized Tribes|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref> In fact, informally the tribes had already been working jointly on projects. In March, 1949, Belvin had gone to [[Washington, DC]] not only to prod lawmakers regarding the coal and asphalt settlement, but to present a proposal drawn up by representatives of the five tribes as a far-reaching "relief" plan. They proposed more effective administration of Indian affairs, a new land policy, rehabilitation, education, health, conservation, and road building and maintenance as the means to alleviate distress in their nations and had obtained the endorsement from the local agency office.<ref name="ITC - Ardmore 1949">{{cite news|title=Belvin Home From Washington: Reports on Indian Situation|url=http://www.myheritage.es/research/collection-10025/archivo-de-periodicos?itemId=594520081&action=showRecord|accessdate=11 January 2015|agency=Ardmore Daily Ardmoreite|date=23 March 1949|location=Ardmore, Oklahoma}}</ref>
In September and October 1949, the leaders of the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] met in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]] and formed the Inter-Tribal Council of the Five Civilized Tribes (ITC). They pledged to work together to attain for themselves and their descendants the rights and benefits which they were entitled to under law, state or federal, and to seek equity for tribal affairs and tribe members by promoting the common welfare of American Indians. The constitution of the organization was approved on February 3, 1950. Inter-Tribal Council membership includes the principal chief and four members from each of the [[Cherokee Nation|Cherokee]], [[Chickasaw Nation|Chickasaw]], [[Choctaw Nation|Choctaw]], [[Creek Nation|Creek]] and [[Seminole Nation of Oklahoma|Seminole]] nations.<ref name="Intertribal Council" />
Belvin served on the ITC from its founding in 1949 through 1975.<ref name="ITC History" /> After obtaining Congressional approval, and pressing for the withdrawal of [[House concurrent resolution 108|House Concurrent Resolution 108]], the ITC has spent over a half-century of activity focusing on education, health care, housing, and sovereignty to serve the special cultural, economic, and social needs of all tribespeople.<ref name="Intertribal Council" />
===Termination=== As part of the [[Indian termination policy]] pursued by the US government from the 1940s through the 1960s, a series of laws were passed to enable the government to end its trust relationships with native tribes. One of the first of these laws passed on August 13, 1946—the [[Indian Claims Commission]] Act of 1946, Pub. L. No. 79-726, ch. 959. Its purpose was to settle for all time any outstanding grievances or claims the tribes might have against the U.S. for treaty breaches, unauthorized taking of land, dishonorable or unfair dealings, or inadequate compensation. Claims had to be filed within a five-year period, and most of the 370 complaints that were submitted were filed at the approach of the 5-year deadline in August, 1951.<ref name="Philip (1999)">{{cite book|last1=Philp|first1=Kenneth R.|title=Termination revisited : American Indians on the trail to self-determination, 1933-1953|date=1999|publisher=Univ. of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln [u.a.]|isbn=0-8032-3723-5|pages=21–33|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68ggiC4QtRkC&lpg|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> In 1946, the government had appropriated funds for the tribal sale of coal and asphalt resources, but had charged almost 10% of the $8.5 million award in administrative fees.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)">{{cite journal|last1=Kidwell|first1=Clara Sue|title=The Resurgence of the Choctaws in the Twentieth Century|journal=Indigenous Nations Studies Journal|volume= . 3, No. 1|issue=Spring 2002|pages=10–12|url=http://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/bitstream/handle/1808/5782/ins.v03.n1.3-18.pdf?sequence=1|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref>
When Belvin became chief in 1948, he realized that only federally recognized tribes were allowed to file a claim with the Commission. If he wanted to get that money back, his tribe needed to reorganize. He created a democratically elected tribal council and a constitution to re-establish a government, but his efforts were opposed by the Area Director of the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]]. Ultimately, the tribe was able to file a claim for around $750,000 with the Commission in 1951 on a technicality. The suit was classified as a renewal of the 1944 case against the US Court of Claims, but that did not stop the antagonism between Belvin and the area BIA officials.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)" /> The BIA had had management issues for decades. Poorly trained personnel, inefficiency, corruption, and lack of consistent policy plagued the organization almost from its founding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.downsizinggovernment.org/interior/indian-lands-indian-subsidies|title=Indian Lands, Indian Subsidies,|work=Downsizing the Federal Government}}</ref> For Belvin, relief from BIA oversight of policies and funds seemed as if it might pave the way for the Choctaw to maintain their own traditional ways of operating and reform their own governing council.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)" />
Early on, it may also be that Belvin believed termination was what the tribe wanted. In a 1954 presentation to the [[Five Civilized Tribes|Intertribal Council of the Five Civilized Tribes]], he told the chiefs of the [[Cherokee Nation|Cherokee]], [[Chickasaw Nation|Chickasaw]], [[Muscogee (Creek) Nation|Creek]] and [[Seminole Nation of Oklahoma|Seminole]] nations that the majority of [[Choctaw Nation|Choctaw]] were not interested in tribal affairs and supported discontinuance of the tribe.<ref name="Lambert 2007, p 66"/> But, he also stated in an interview that same year with the ''Lubbock Avalanche,'' that he thought proposing termination was another way for the government to "shirk its responsibility to a people who owned the entire continent of North America when the white man first invaded, not discovered, this country".<ref name="Lubbock (1954)">{{cite news|last1=Considine|first1=Bob|title=Bill Would Be a Blow to Redmen: U.S. Continues War on Indian Tribes with Legislative Bullet|url=http://www.myheritage.es/research/collection-10025/archivo-de-periodicos?itemId=688307153&action=showRecord|accessdate=11 January 2015|publisher=Lubbock Morning Avalanche|date=31 March 1954|location=Lubbock, Texas}}</ref>
After eleven years as Choctaw chief, Belvin persuaded Representative [[Carl Albert]] of Oklahoma to introduce federal legislation to begin terminating the Choctaw tribe.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)" /> What Belvin proposed was relief from the paternalistic watch of the BIA, which allowed the tribe to choose their own chiefs and handle tribal business and assets without federal supervision.<ref name="Brownwood (1970)">{{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Godfrey|title=Indians Ready Peace Pipe -- Repeal Bill Due Senate Action|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/6741102/|accessdate=9 January 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Brownwood Bulletin|date=August 19, 1970|location=Brownwood, Texas|page=7}}</ref> On 23 April 1959, the BIA confirmed that H.R.2722, had been submitted to Congress at the request of the tribe, and would sell all remaining tribal assets, but would not effect any individual Choctaw earnings. It also provided for retention of 1/2 of all mineral rights which could be managed by a tribal corporation.<ref name="BIA - 23 April 1959">{{cite web|title=Department Supports Choctaw Termination Bill Introduced in Congress at the Request of Tribal Representatives|url=http://www.bia.gov/cs/groups/public/documents/text/idc016731.pdf|publisher=Department of the Interior|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
On 25 August 1959, Congress passed a bill<ref name="Public Law 86-192">{{cite web|title=Public Law 86-192|url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/Vol6/html_files/v6p0882.html|publisher=US Code|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> to terminate the tribe, which was later called ''Belvin's law,'' as he was the main advocate behind it. Belvin created overwhelming support for termination among tribespeople through his promotion of the bill, describing the process and expected outcomes.<ref name="Lambert AIQ Vol. 31" /> What Belvin envisioned was that the high unemployment and poverty which existed in the nation, would be offset by the per capita payment that tribe members would receive from liquidation of the tribal assets.<ref name="Lambert 2007, p 66"/> Tribal members later interviewed said that Belvin never used the word "termination" for what he was describing, and many people were unaware he was proposing termination.<ref name="Lambert AIQ Vol. 31">{{cite journal|last1=Lambert|first1=Valerie|title=Political Protest, Conflict, and Tribal Nationalism: The Oklahoma Choctaws and the Termination Crisis of 1959–1970|journal=American Indian Quarterly|volume= 31, No. 2|issue=Spring 2007|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/4138948?sid=21105014084301&uid=70&uid=4&uid=3738664&uid=2129&uid=2|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|doi=10.2307/4138948}}</ref> In actuality, the provisions of the bill were intended to be a final disposition of all trust obligations and a final "dissolution of the tribal governments."<ref name="BIA - 23 April 1959"/> Belvin claimed that he was misled and that the BIA did not pass the legislation the Choctaw proposed, as it did affect individual Choctaws and the relationships they had with the government and programs.<ref name="Ardmore (1970)">{{cite news|title=Washington (AP)|url=http://www.myheritage.es/research/collection-10025/archivo-de-periodicos?itemId=594424183&action=showRecord|accessdate=11 January 2015|publisher=Ardmore Daily Ardmoreite|date=15 July 1970|location=Ardmore, Oklahoma}}</ref>
The original Act was to have expired in 1962, but was amended twice to allow more time to sell the tribal assets. As time wore on, Belvin realized that the bill severed the tribe members' access to government loans and other services, including the tribal tax exemption. By 1967, he had asked Oklahoma Congressman [[Ed Edmondson (politician)|Ed Edmondson]] to try to repeal the termination act.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)" /> Belvin's views were not just contained in private letters. In a 1967 newspaper account, he stated that the tribe needed to determine whether to outright repeal the 1959 Choctaw Termination Act or whether they wanted to form a tribal corporation to manage tribal affairs without supervision of the federal government.<ref name="Ada News">{{cite news|title=Chief J.W. Harry Belvin said!|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/us/oklahoma/ada/ada-evening-news/1967/03-31/page-3|accessdate=7 January 2015|publisher=Ada Evening News|date=March 31, 1967|page=3}}</ref> In addition, both Oklahomans, House Majority Leader [[Carl Albert]] and Senator [[Fred R. Harris]], as well as [[Louis R. Bruce]], Commissioner of Indian Affairs, were in support of the Choctaw request to kill the bill.<ref name="Ardmore (1970)" />
By the late 1960s public sentiment was changing as well. The Choctaw people had seen what termination could do to tribes, since they witnessed the process with four other tribes in Oklahoma: the [[Wyandotte Nation]], [[Peoria tribe|Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma]], [[Ottawa Tribe of Oklahoma]], and [[Modoc Tribe of Oklahoma]]. In 1969, ten years after passage of the Choctaw termination bill and one year before the Choctaws were to be terminated, word spread throughout the tribe that Belvin's law was a termination bill. The [[Choctaw Youth Movement]] fought politically against the termination law and helped create a new sense of tribal pride, especially among younger generations. Congress finally repealed the law on August 24, 1970.<ref name="Lambert AIQ Vol. 31" />
===Choctaw Youth Movement=== {{main|Choctaw Youth Movement}} In 1969, one year before the termination bill was scheduled to go into effect (officially 25 August 1970) Jim Wade, son of Talihina's police chief, told [[Charles E. Brown (Choctaw)|Charles E. Brown]], that the government was dissolving the Choctaw tribe.<ref>Lambert (2007), pp 64-65</ref> Alarmed, and believing that most Choctaw did not realize "Belvin's law" was a termination bill rather than a per capita payment bill, Brown began organizing other urban Choctaw, primarily in the Oklahoma City area. With a key group of organizers they began using kin networks to contact Choctaw relatives throughout the country and traditional Choctaw Nation to urge them to fight against termination and be proud of their Choctaw heritage.<ref>Lambert (2007), pp 66-70</ref> They printed a newsletter called ''Hello Choctaws''<ref name="Kidwell (2007)">{{cite book|last1= Kidwell|first1=Clara Sue ; foreword by Lindsay G. Robertson|title=The Choctaws in Oklahoma : from tribe to nation, 1855-1970|date=2007|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=978-0-8061-3826-8|pages=216–217|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5HpLmevAz3YC&lpg|accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref> and lobbied Congress and the BIA to stop termination.<ref>Lambert (2007), pp 69-70</ref> It is clear that the youth activists felt Belvin was in favor of termination and that he was a traitor to tribal objectives. It is equally clear that Belvin felt that activists were personally attacking him and that he scheduled meetings throughout the Choctaw Nation to justify his actions.<ref>Lambert (2007), pp 73-75</ref>
It is hard to judge the effectiveness of the Choctaw Youth Movement in actually overturning the termination legislation. Public sentiment was changing with the passage of the [[Indian Civil Rights Act of 1968]],<ref name="Wunder (1996)">{{cite book|last1=Wunder|first1=edited with introductions by John R.|title=The Indian Bill of Rights, 1968|date=1996|publisher=Garland Pub.|location=New York|isbn=0-8153-2487-1|pages=78–81|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xRR2B2q5wxkC&lpg|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref> the Supreme Court ruling in the [[Menominee Tribe v. United States]] decision<ref name=Menominee>{{cite web|title=Menominee Tribe of Indians v. United States, 391 U.S. 404 (1968)|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/391/404/case.html|accessdate=9 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111204528/https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/391/404/case.html|archivedate=11 January 2015|df=}}</ref> and even President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] was advocating for policy which "ends the old debate about "termination" of Indian programs and stresses self-determination".<ref name="Johnson (1968)">{{cite web|title=Special Message to the Congress on the Problems of the American Indian: "The Forgotten American."|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=28709|accessdate=9 January 2015|date=March 6, 1968}}</ref> Belvin had been speaking publicly and pressing legislators to overturn the legislation for at least 2 years and he was a proponent of tribes having the autonomy to elect their own leadership.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)" /> In those goals, he and the youth activists were not far apart, as, after stopping termination, one of the activist's primary goals was the ability to elect their own tribal chief. Activists saw the BIA appointment of their leadership as an infringement on their identity as a sovereign people.<ref name="Kidwell (2007)" />
Where Belvin and youth activists differed was that Belvin seemed to see the tribe as a simple corporate entity whose role was to manage tribal assets. Activists saw the tribe as a multifaceted organization which spurred community development and fostered Choctaw identity.<ref>Kidwell (2007), p 213</ref> What the movement did in unequivocal terms was foster pride in being Choctaw and brought about a rebirth in Choctaw nationalism.<ref>Lambert (2007), p 72</ref>
===Indian Education=== As a teacher and educator, Belvin had on ongoing interest in furthering education for Native Americans. He participated in the 1956 [[American Indian Institute]] Conference at the [[University of Oklahoma]] and urged that education had to include teaching underprivileged Indians the skills necessary to earn a living. He acknowledged that while education would bring about economic change, for Indians to progress they "could not neglect the culture and heritage" that they had contributed to the country. Belvin agreed to serve on the Institute's planning committee for the following year.<ref name="American Indian Institute">{{cite web|title=American Indian Institute|url=http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/whc/nam/manuscripts/Campbell_WS_119_11.pdf|publisher=Western History Collections, University of Oklahoma|accessdate=10 January 2015|location=Norman, Oklahoma|pages=12–13|date=17 March 1956|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723125722/http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/whc/nam/manuscripts/Campbell_WS_119_11.pdf#|archive-date=2010-07-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In 1959, a dispute among the Mississippi Choctaw found Belvin encouraging support for a Choctaw high school in Mississippi. Victor Kaneubbe, a worker at a Baptist mission in [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]] was an Oklahoma Choctaw with a white wife and a mixed-blood daughter, who was unable to attend either the agency schools or white schools in Mississippi. Choctaw administrators refused to allow his daughter admittance and the Neshoba County School Board refused admittance as well. He brought the issue of racism to the fore and urged his missionary network to petition Congress for creation of a Choctaw high school. The adverse publicity enraged the Baptist community, and cost Kaneubbe his job, forcing him to transfer to the Navajo reservation. Kaneubbe left but the problem of inadequate education remained for eastern Choctaw. Appeals to the BIA resulted in responses that students could attend out of state boarding schools, thus squarely putting pressure on the eastern Choctaw to relocate or face lack of educational opportunity. Agitation from the [[National Congress of American Indians]], the [[Mississippi Federation of Women's Clubs]], Oklahoma Choctaw Chief Belvin, and other civil rights activists forced Mississippi's congressional delegation to request a high school and dormitory for the [[Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians]], though it took several more years of negotiation to make the high school become a reality.<ref name="Osburn (2014)">{{cite book|last1=Osburn|first1=Katherine M. B.|title=Choctaw resurgence in Mississippi : race, class, and nation building in the jim crow south, 1830-1977|date=2014|publisher=University of Nebraska|isbn=978-0-8032-4044-5|pages=192–197|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GCeXAwAAQBAJ&lpg|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref>
Belvin was acutely aware that his generation had been urged to learn [[English language|English]] and not [[Choctaw language|Choctaw]], but claims that his father's encouragement to speak only English had caused Belvin to advocate for full assimilation and favor eliminating the study of Choctaw,<ref name="Akers (2013)" /><ref>Lambert (2007), p 85</ref> are not born out by his work in education. Belvin remained involved with his alma mater, Southeastern State College (now [[Southeastern Oklahoma State University]]) in Durant. Around 1969, with Belvin and other educators' full support and input, the college began a Bilingual Education Program, which was sponsored by a grant from the [[United States Department of Health, Education, and Welfare]] National Institute of Education. The program targeted four elementary schools in the heart of Choctaw country, [[Battiest, Oklahoma|Battiest]], [[Broken Bow, Oklahoma|Broken Bow]], [[Smithville, Oklahoma|Smithville]] and [[Wright City, Oklahoma|Wright City]] in McCurtain County, Oklahoma. The program, as designed had 3 principal goals, all aimed at mainstreaming the student without sacrificing his/her native identity:
* Students should have positive image reinforcement both inside and outside of the classroom; * [[Choctaw language]] must be accepted to be the basis for learning as the student develops a facility with English which will supplement learning; * Teachers and classroom attendants must understand Choctaw language, thought patterns and behavior and accept those as equal to their English counterparts.<ref name="Choctaw Bilingual Program">{{cite journal|editor1-last=Bowen|editor1-first=Collin W.|title=Choctaw Bilingual Education Program: Distinguished Achievement Awards Entry|journal=Education Resources Information Center (ERIC)|date=19 November 1973|pages=1–4|url=http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED085363.pdf|accessdate=12 January 2015|publisher=Southeastern State College|location=Durant, Oklahoma}}</ref>
The program continued until around 1982, when federal funding initiatives were cut.<ref name="Southeastern (1982)">{{cite news|last1=Lokey|first1=Ray|title=Choctaw Bilingual Center May Fade to History|url=http://carmine.se.edu/digitized-annuals/The%20Southeastern/Newspapers/1982/3%20-%20March/March%2011,%201982.pdf|accessdate=12 January 2015|issue=Volume 60; Number 26|publisher=Soulheastem Oklahoma Stale University|date=11 March 1982|location=Durant, Oklahoma|page=1}}</ref>
===Indian Health=== In 1955, the Indian Health Service was transferred from the administration of the BIA to the [[Public Health Service]], which resulted in an almost immediate improvement in funding, training and services.<ref name="Sturtevant (1988)">{{cite book|editor1-last=Sturtevant|editor1-first=William C.|title=Handbook of North American Indians: History of Indian-White relations, Vol. 4|date=1988|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|isbn=0-16-004583-5|lccn=77017162|pages=77–78|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yQRpEgEzYd4C&lpg|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> At that time, the Talihina Indian Hospital (now known as the [[Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma#Health System|Choctaw Nation Health Care Center]]) was designated as the Public Health Service Indian Hospital and was the chief facility in [[Oklahoma]] providing comprehensive, preventative and other treatment services for the Choctaw.<ref name="Choctaw Health System">{{cite web|last1=Pyle|first1=Gregory E.|title=Having Options Making Choices – The Choctaw Nation Health Care System|url=http://www.ok.gov/abletech/documents/Indian%20Health%20Service%20Offices.pdf|website=OK.gov|accessdate=13 January 2015|page=2|date=21 August 2011}}</ref> Belvin worked with Floyd Gale Anderson, the first full-blood Indian to hold the position of Service Unit Director, to expand the Choctaw health system. Under their tutelage, to make health care more accessible, satellite clinics were opened in [[Broken Bow, Oklahoma|Broken Bow]], [[Hugo, Oklahoma|Hugo]] and [[McAlester, Oklahoma|McAlester]].<ref name="Anderson obit">{{cite news|title=ANDERSON -- Floyd Gale|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/anderson/article_74cb149b-8e4e-547e-b94a-e8eb36b463af.html|accessdate=13 January 2015|publisher=Tulsa World|date=9 December 2003}}</ref>
Also during Belvin's term, in 1969. the Choctaw Nation created a Community Health Representative Program to help those Indians residing within the tribal service area of the Choctaw Nation boundaries to maintain health for their families.<ref name="Health Representative Program">{{cite web|title=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma Programs and Services|url=http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/utils/getfile/collection/choctawnat/id/7707/filename/7708.pdf|accessdate=13 January 2015|page=7}}</ref> The program targets people who predominantly reside in rural settings and may not be near medical facilities<ref name=Faiman-Silva>{{cite book|last1=Faiman-Silva|first1=Sandra|title=Choctaws at the crossroads : the political economy of class and culture in the Oklahoma timber region|date=1997|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln|isbn=0-8032-2001-4|page=164|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DS5LgMyvYNAC&lpg|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> and assists them with health checks, monitoring health issues, nutritional needs, education, and referral services.<ref name="Health Representative Program" />
===Choctaw Nation Housing Authority=== In the 1960s as part of the [[War on Poverty]] programs introduced by [[Lyndon B. Johnson|President Lyndon B. Johnson]], Belvin submitted an application to the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD) to create a tribal housing authority.<ref name="Lambert 2007, pp 75-77">Lambert (2007), pp 75-77</ref> He realized that Federal programs administered by the Bureau of Indian Affairs were aimed primarily at reservation communities, and the unique status of Oklahoma tribes without extensive land bases, meant that many programs designed for Indians did not benefit the Five Civilized Tribes.<ref>Kidwell (2007), p 211-212</ref> He further had become aware that programs which the BIA had offered for loans, had evaporated with the enactment of the termination bill.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)" /> HUD denied Belvin's application based on various reasons, but included that the Choctaw were not policing tribal lands. In 1966,<ref name="McKee (1980)">{{cite book|last1=McKee|first1=Jesse O.|last2=Schlenker|first2=Jon A.|title=The Choctaws : cultural evolution of a native American tribe|date=1980|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|location=Jackson, Miss.|isbn=0-87805-107-4|page=183|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tf6CjSn17wgC&lpg|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref> he then resubmitted the application under the requirements for a state agency,<ref name="Lambert 2007, pp 75-77"/> rather than a tribal authority, and designated himself, as chief, with the powers vested in a mayor for the purposes of the Act. According to the state requirements, a 5-person board of commissioners was appointed to oversee the housing authority.<ref name="Housing Authority (1979)">{{cite web|title=Housing Authority Of Choctaw Nation v. Craytor|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/oklahoma/supreme-court/1979/48077.html|website=Justia U.S. Law|accessdate=9 January 2015|date=26 June 1979}}</ref>
By 1971, 364 homes<ref name="Lambert 2007, pp 75-77"/> designed for low-income Indian families to purchase or rehabilitate housing<ref name="Mututal Help">{{cite web|title=Mutual Help Homeownership Opportunity Program for Indian Areas|url=http://portal.hud.gov/hudportal/HUD?src=/programdescription/muthelp|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref> and 116 units of low-rent housing had been finished, with an additional 274 homes under construction.<ref name="Lambert 2007, pp 75-77"/> By 1973, 885 houses had been completed and were occupied and an additional 331 were under construction.<ref name="McKee (1980)" />
==Tribal Election of 1971== On 22 October 1970, the US Congress passed an Act (84 Stat. 1091) authorizing each of the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] to popularly elect their Principal Chief.<ref name="five civilized tribes">{{cite web|title=A Brief History of the Choctaw Nation|url=http://www.fivecivilizedtribes.org/FiveTribes/Choctaw/ChoctawHistory.aspx|website=fivecivilizedtribes.org|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> The BIA selected an election committee of eight Choctaws to determine who would be eligible to vote in the first free election since the [[Dawes Act]]. The committee decided "to permit all lineal descendants of Choctaw by blood Dawes enrollees to vote," which resulted in about 25% of the ballots being from absentee voters.<ref>Lambert (2007), p 77-79</ref> Though Belvin won the election, it would be his last term as chief. His efforts at rebuilding the tribal structure were seen as insignificant and not aggressive enough, his failure to define membership procedures to admit unenrolled descendants of enrolled members, and his lack of planning to develop the tribe led to his defeat in 1975.<ref>Lambert (2007), pp 79-81</ref>
==Offices, Recognition and Awards== * 1947<ref name="Paris News (1948)" />-1953<ref name="Herley (2010)">{{cite web|last1=Herley|first1=Samuel H.|title="The Coming Tide": Viewpoints on the Formation of U.S. Federal Indian Termination Policy, 1945-1954|url=http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/historydiss/30|publisher=University of Nebraska - Lincoln|accessdate=10 January 2015|page=66|date=1 April 2010}}</ref> State President of the Choctaw-Chickasaw Confederation * 1948<ref name="Paris News (1948)" />-1950 President of the Board of Trustees for the [[Goodland Academy]] & Indian Orphanage, Hugo, Oklahoma<ref name="Paris News (1950)">{{cite news|title=Gooland Trustees|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/14256212/|accessdate=11 January 2015|publisher=The Paris News|date=10 October 1950|location=Paris, Texas|page=2}}</ref> * 1948 Chairman of Oklahoma Presbyterian Educational Campaign<ref name="Paris News (1948)" /> * 1949-1975 member of the Inter-Tribal Council of the Five Civilized Tribes<ref name="ITC History"/> * 1957 Outstanding Indian of Oklahoma, Tulsa Indian Democratic Club<ref name="Durant obit" /> * 1959 Outstanding American Indian by the Anadarko Indian Exposition.<ref name="OU - awards">{{cite web|title=Chief Harry Belvin|url=http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/dorisduke/id/9733/rec/|website=The University of Oklahoma|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> * 6 October 1968 was proclaimed by the American Indian Institute of the University of Oklahoma as "Chief Belvin Day" in honor of his service to Indian Education<ref name="Belvin Day">{{cite web|title=CHIEF BELVIN DAY - CHOCTAW|url=http://digital.libraries.ou.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/dorisduke/id/9733/rec/8|website=University of Oklahoma|accessdate=10 January 2015}}</ref> * 1968 - 1972 member Oklahoma City Indian Health Service Advisory Board<ref name="Durant obit" /> * 1968 - 1972 member Surgeon General's Advisory Board on Indian Health<ref name="Durant obit" /> * 1 June 1975 dedicated Harry J. W. Belvin Indian Health Center in [[Hugo, OK]] to honor the Chief<ref name="Spear (1977)">{{cite web|last1=Spear|first1=Eloise G.|title=Choctaw Indian Education With Special Reference To Choctaw County, Oklahoma|url=https://shareok.org/bitstream/handle/11244/4358/7732883.PDF|publisher=University of Oklahoma|accessdate=12 January 2015|location=Norman, OK|page=248|date=1977}}</ref> * 18 July 1975 honored by the Inter-Tribal Council of the Five Civilized Tribes as an Outstanding American Indian Citizen<ref name="ITC History" />
==Personal life== On December 21, 1922, in Boswell, Oklahoma, Belvin married Lucille Brightwell<ref name="Choctaw chief list" /> (25 June 1903 - 24 August 1991).<ref name="Lucille tombstone">{{cite web|title=Lucille Brightwell Belvin|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/35965046|publisher=Find A Grave|accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref> They had one child, Louise Belvin Frazier.<ref name="Choctaw chief list" /> Belvin was an elder in the Presbyterian Church.
He died 19 September 1986 in Bryan Memorial Hospital and was buried in Highland Cemetery, Durant, Oklahoma.<ref name="Obituary - Oklahoman" />
==References==

W.}} [[Category:Choctaw people]] [[Category:Native American tribes in Oklahoma]] [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:People from Durant, Oklahoma]] [[Category:History of Oklahoma]] [[Category:United States federal Indian policy]] [[Category:Native American politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Oklahoma House of Representatives]] [[Category:Oklahoma state senators]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox philosopher | main_interests = [[International relations]] | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1932|6|10}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1985|5|18|1932|6|10}} | death_place = [[Oxford]], [[United Kingdom]] | nationality = [[British nationality law|British]] (as of 1965)<ref name="Ayson">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_gV6DDWN6rAC|p=51|quote=In accepting the nomination... Bull would take up British citizenship (which meant an unexpected forfeiting of his formal Australian identity).|title=Hedley Bull and the Accommodation of Power|author=R. Ayson|publisher=[[Springer Publishing]]|year=2012|isbn=9781137291509}}</ref> | alma_mater = [[University of Sydney]] | institutions = {{ubl|[[Australian National University]]|[[London School of Economics and Political Science]]|[[University of Oxford]]}} | school_tradition = [[English school of international relations theory|English School]] | influences = [[John Anderson (philosopher)|John Anderson]] | influenced = | notable_ideas = Society of states }}
'''Hedley Norman Bull''', [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]] (10 June 1932 – 18 May 1985) was Professor of [[International Relations]] at the [[Australian National University]], the [[London School of Economics]] and the [[University of Oxford]] until his death from cancer in 1985. He was [[Montague Burton Professor of International Relations]] at Oxford from 1977 to 1985, and died there.<ref name="ANU Obituary">{{cite web|url=http://oa.anu.edu.au/obituary/bull-hedley-norman-175|title=Bull, Hedley Norman (1932–1985)|publisher=oa.anu.edu.au|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref>
==Biography== Bull was born in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]], where he attended [[Fort Street High School]]. He went on to study history and philosophy at the [[University of Sydney]], where he was strongly influenced by the philosopher [[John Anderson (philosopher)|John Anderson]]. In 1953, Bull left Australia to study politics at Oxford, and after two years he was appointed to an assistant lectureship in international relations at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE).
In 1965, Bull was appointed director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Unit of the [[British Foreign Office]], forfeiting his Australian identity for British citizenship.<ref name="Ayson"/> Two years later, in 1967, he was appointed to a professorship of international relations at the Australian National University (ANU) in [[Canberra]].
In 1977, Bull published his main work, ''[[The Anarchical Society]]''. It is widely regarded as a key textbook in the field of international relations and is also seen as the central text in the so-called '[[English school of international relations theory|English School]]' of [[international relations]]. In this book, he argues that despite the [[Anarchism|anarchical]] character of the international arena, it is characterised by the formation of not only a system of states, but a society of states. His requirements for an entity to be called a [[Sovereign state|state]] are that it must claim [[sovereignty]] over (i) a group of [[People#In politics|people]] (ii) a defined territory, and that it must have a [[government]]. States form a system when they have a sufficient degree of interaction, and impact on each other's decisions, so as they "behave — at least in some measure — as parts of a whole." A system of states can exist without it also being a society of states. A society of states comes into existence "when a group of states, conscious of certain common interests and common values, form a society in the sense that they conceive themselves to be bound by a common set of rules in their relations with one another, and share in the working of common institutions."
The society of states is a way for Bull to analyse and assess possibilities of order in [[Geopolitics|world politics]]. He continues his argument by giving the concept of [[social order|order]] in social life, and the mechanisms of: the [[balance of power in international relations|balance of power]], [[international law]], [[diplomacy]], [[war]] and the [[great powers]] central roles. He finally concludes that, despite the existence of possible alternative forms of organization, the states system is our best chance of achieving order in world politics.
==Selected works== *''The control of the arms race: Disarmament and arms control in the missile age'' (1965) *''Strategic studies and its critics'' (1967) *''[[The Anarchical Society]]: A Study of Order in World Politics'' (1977) *''The Expansion of International Society'', co-edited with [[Adam Watson]] (1984). *''Intervention in World Politics'' (1984) *''Justice in international relations'' (1984) (1983-84 Hagey lectures) *'' The Challenge of the Third Reich'' (1986) (The Adam von Trott Memorial Lectures) *{{cite book|editor=(with [[Adam Roberts (scholar)|Adam Roberts]] and Benedict Kingsbury)|title=Hugo Grotius and International Relations, ''Oxford University Press, 1990''|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/hugo-grotius-and-international-relations-9780198277712?cc=gb&lang=en&}}{{ISBN|0-19-825569-1}} (hardback); {{ISBN|0-19-827771-7}} (paperback). [https://web.archive.org/web/20110629175420/http://www.oup.com/us/catalog/general/subject/Law/PublicInternationalLaw/GeneralPublicInternationalLaw/?view=usa&ci=9780198277712 ''US edition.''] [http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/oso/public/content/politicalscience/9780198277712/toc.html ''Oxford Scholarship Online''.] [https://books.google.com/books?id=Um7O_u-W4EcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Hugo+Grotius+and+International+Relations&hl=en&src=bmrr&ei=_DyKTZSqDM-EhQeUwLWkDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false ''On Google''].
There is a comprehensive bibliography of Hedley Bull's works (prepared by [[Donald Markwell]]) in * J. D. B. Miller & [[R J Vincent]] (eds), ''Order and Violence'', Oxford University Press, 1990, and *[[Robert J. O'Neill]] & David N. Schwartz (eds), ''Hedley Bull on Arms Control'', Macmillan, 1987.
==See also== *[[New medievalism]] *[[Domestic analogy]] *''[[The Anarchical Society]]'' *[[Montague Burton Professor of International Relations]]
==Citations== {{reflist}}
==General References== *Coral Bell and Meredith Thatcher (eds.), [http://epress.anu.edu.au/sdsc/hedley/mobile_devices/index.html ''Remembering Hedley''], ANU Press, anu.edu.au (2008). *Alderson, Kai and [[Andrew Hurrell]] ''Hedley Bull On International Society'' (2003) *[[Donald Markwell]], ''"Instincts to lead": on leadership, peace, and education'' (2013) *Miller, J.D.B. and [[R J Vincent]] (eds), ''Order and Violence: Hedley Bull and International Relations'' (1990) *Vigezzi, Brunello ''The British Committee on the Theory of International Politics'' (2005) *Michele Chiaruzzi, 'In Search of International Order', in F. Andreatta (ed), ''Great Works in International Relations'' (2017).
{{Authority control}}

{{no footnotes|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Hüsnüşah Hatun | title = Ümdet-ül- muhadderat
Tâc-i mestürat
Iklilet-i Aliyyet-üz-zat | image = Muradiye Complex, exterior 2.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = The mausoleum of "Hüsnüşah Hatun" is located inside [[Muradiye Complex]], [[Bursa]] | spouse = [[Bayezid II]] | issue = Şehzade Şehinşah
Sultanzade Hatun | father = Nasuh Bey | mother = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Karamanids|Karamanid Principality]] | death_date = {{circa}} 1513 | death_place = [[Bursa]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | burial_place = [[Muradiye Complex]], [[Bursa]] | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] }} [[File:Husnusah Hatuniye Mosque 2.jpg|thumb|150px|The exterior view of Hatuniye Mosque]] '''Hüsnüşah Hatun''' (died c. 1513), was a consort of Sultan [[Bayezid II]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. ==Life== Hüsnüşah Hatun was born in 1454 to a Nasuh Bey. Bayezid was still a şehzade and the governor of Amasya sanjak when she gave birth to Şehzade Şehinşah in 1474, followed by Sultanzade Hatun. According to Turkish tradition, all princes were expected to work as provincial governors as a part of their training. In 1481 Şehinşah, was sent to Manisa sanjak and then in 1483 to [[Karaman Province|Karaman]], and Hüsnüşah accompanied him. She built and endowed a mosque at [[Manisa]] in 1490. After Şehzade Şehinşah's death in 1511, Hüsnüşah Hatun came to [[Bursa]]. Hüsnüşah Hatun also corresponded with [[Selim I]], Şehinşah's victorious brother, on behalf of Mevlana Pir Ahmed Çelebi, a scholar who had been at Şehinşah's court and who was neglected when the members of the prince's household were assigned new posts. She lies buried in [[Muradiye Complex]], [[Bursa]]. ==Sources== *{{cite book|author=M. Çağatay Uluçay|title=Padişahların kadınları ve kızları|publisher=Türk Tarih Kurumu|year=1985|isbn=|ref=Uluçay}} *{{cite book|author=Necdet Sakaoğlu|title=Bu mülkün kadın sultanları: Vâlide sultanlar, hâtunlar, hasekiler, kadınefendiler, sultanefendiler |publisher=Oğlak Yayıncılık|year=2008|isbn=978-9-753-29623-6|ref=Sakaoğlu}} *{{cite book|author=Leslie P. Peirce|title=The Imperial Harem: Women and Sovereignty in the Ottoman Empire|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1993|isbn=978-0-195-08677-5|ref=Peirce}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Husnusah Hatun}} [[Category:Wives of Ottoman Sultans]] [[Category:1454 births]] [[Category:1513 deaths]] [[Category:15th-century people of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:15th-century women of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:16th-century Ottoman royalty]] [[Category:16th-century women of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Princesses]]

[[File:Albert Einstein and others letter.jpg|thumbnail|Albert Einstein, Irma Lindheim and others letter]] '''Irma L. Lindheim''' (1886–1978), born in New York, was a [[Zionist]] fund-raiser and educator.<ref name="bare_url">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SH8r3ntJG8AC&pg=PA127&dq=%22irma+lindheim%22&hl=en&ei=vbSAT7STA-aY0QGyrOydCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=5&ved=0CE8Q6wEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22irma%20lindheim%22&f=false |title=Gender and Judaism: The Transformation of Tradition - Tamar Rudavsky - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref><ref name="bare_url_a">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gEj0oLYK10sC&pg=PA857&dq=%22irma+lindheim%22&hl=en&ei=vbSAT7STA-aY0QGyrOydCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=4&ved=0CEkQ6wEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22irma%20lindheim%22&f=false |title=Jewish Women in America: A-L - Paula Hyman, Deborah Dash Moore, American Jewish Historical Society - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref>
== Early life == Lindheim was born '''Irma Levy''' in [[New York City]] on December 9, 1886, to a German-Jewish family with roots in the American South.<ref name="bare_url_a" /> Her father, Robert Levy, was a business man, and her mother, Mathilda (née Morgenstern) stayed at home and raised Irma and her sisters, Amy and Edna. Though Lindheim would later attend a Jewish seminary, her early life at home was largely devoid of Jewish ritual; the family had Christmas trees in their home and declined to celebrate Jewish holidays.<ref name="bare_url_a" />
Irma, refusing to consent to her father's insistence that he choose her husband, married Norvin R. Lindheim in 1907, a young attorney and graduate of [[Johns Hopkins University|Johns Hopkins]] and [[Columbia Law School|Columbia University Law School]]. Together, they had five children, and when Irma's father died in 1914, she inherited a small fortune.
== Initial Zionist activity == She served as the only Jewish female first lieutenant in the Motor Corps of America during [[World War I]], starting in 1917.<ref name="bare_url" /><ref name="bare_url_a" /> Around this time, Lindheim, inspired by an Ethical Culture teacher, decided to further educate herself on her [[Judaism]]. After visiting her husband's cousin in [[Baltimore]], where she met American Zionists and Palestinian Jews, she decided to dedicate herself to [[Zionism]].<ref name="bare_url_a" /> She began to lecture on the subject, and, recognizing her leadership potential, [[Henrietta Szold]], head of the cultural division of the [[American Zionist Organization]], named Lindehim to the chair of New York's Seventh Zionist District. There, she oversaw the creation of a cultural center, the opening of which was attended by prominent Zionist and [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] Justice Louis [[Louis Brandeis|Brandeis]].<ref name="bare_url_a" /> Though the center was initially successful, a dispute between Brandeis and [[Chaim Weizmann]] at the 1921 Zionist Convention led to the closing of the center.<ref name="bare_url_a" />
=== Rabbinical education === In 1922 she entered the Jewish Institute of Religion in New York City, becoming the first woman in the U.S. to attend a Jewish seminary. As the first female student of the Institute, she was relegated to special student status. In 1923, she petitioned the faculty to change her status from that of [[Matriculation#Special_student|special student]] to a regular student in the rabbinic program; in response, in May of that year they unanimously recommended the admission of women to the Institute on the same basis as men.<ref name="bare_url" /> However, in 1925, she decided to drop her studies and traveled to Palestine.
=== First visit to Palestine === During her visit (later described in her book, ''The Immortal Adventure'', published in 1928), Lindehim was able to attend the opening ceremony of [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem|Hebrew University]] and was introduced to [[Manya Shochat|Manya Shohat]], who would later become a lifelong friend. Shoat helped Lindheim tour the country, taking her to the kibbutz she called home, [[Kfar Giladi|K'far Giladi]]. After touring the [[Negev]], Lindheim was newly energized for the Zionist cause.
== Hadassah presidency == After a short period of fundraising, Lindheim became the second president of [[Hadassah]], in 1926.<ref name="bare_url_a" /> At the time, the [[Zionist Organization of America]], then-president [[Louis Lipsky]] was pressuring Hadassah to give up their autonomy and fold into the ZOA. Lindheim fought against that pressure and eventually succeeded, was re-elected president in 1927, and served as Hadassah's delegate to the [[World Zionist Congress]] in [[Basel]]. When she returned, she joined the [[Labor Zionism|Labor Zionist]] [[Poale Zion]], prompting the Hadassah board to demand her resignation on the grounds of conflict of interest. Lindheim resigned her post and began to raise funds for [[Histadrut]] and [[Hashomer Hatzair]], organizations that defined themselves as further left than Hadassah.<ref name="bare_url_a" />
== Back to Palestine == In March 1933, Lindheim moved to Palestine with her children (Norvin had died in 1928) and attempted to found a Histadrut-funded clearing house for new immigrants. Finding this unfulfilling, she moved to Kibbutz [[Mishmar HaEmek]].<ref name="bare_url_a" /> At 47, she was about 25 years older than the average kibbutz member.<ref name="bare_url_a" />
During World War II, she was drafted by [[Jewish National Fund|Keren Kayemet]] to solicit funding for Zionist causes in England. She also remained active in prodding Hadassah during this time, petitioning them to increase their work with the Zionist youth movement. Briefly moving back to America, she mounted an unsuccessful congressional campaign as candidate for the [[American Labor Party]] in [[Queens]], New York, in 1948 (when she appeared at rallies for Progressive presidential candidate [[Henry A. Wallace]] and ran with Brooklyn ALP candidate [[Lee Pressman]]), sending her back to what was now Israel.<ref> {{cite news | first = James A. | last = Hagerty | title = 48,000 Hear Wallace Assert Prejudice Will Fail in South | publisher = New York Times | page = 1 | date = 11 September 1948 | accessdate = 28 November 2017}}</ref>
There, she helped to create Kibbutz [[Adamit]] and Kibbutz [[Ein HaShofet]]. ''Shofet'', which means "judge" in Hebrew, was chosen to honor Louis Brandeis. Dubbed the "grandmother of the kibbutz" by the Israeli press, she moved back to the U.S. in the mid-60's, continuing to write articles and essays for Zionist publications.
In 1962 she published her autobiography ''Parallel Quest: A Search of a Person and a People''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/lindheim-irma-levy|title=Irma Levy Lindheim | Jewish Women's Archive|date=|publisher=Jwa.org|accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref>
Lindheim died on April 10, 1978, in Berkeley, California.
== Some published works == Lindheim, Irma (1928) ''The Immortal Adventure.'' The Macauley Company
Lindheim, Irma (1962) ''Parallel Quest: A Search of a Person and People''. New York.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://digifindingaids.cjh.org/?pID=2916671 Guide to the Hadassah Archives on Long-term Deposit] at the [[American Jewish Historical Society]] * The personal papers of Irma Lindheim are kept at the [http://www.zionistarchives.org.il/en/Pages/Default.aspx Central Zionist Archives] in Jerusalem. The notation of the record group is A274.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lindheim, Irma}} [[Category:Zionists]] [[Category:Jewish scholars]] [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:Hadassah Women's Zionist Organization of America]]

{{redirect|The Golden Bear|other uses|Golden Bear (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox golfer | name = Jack Nicklaus | image = JackNicklaus.cropped.jpg | image_size = 230 | caption = Nicklaus in September 2006 | fullname = Jack William Nicklaus | nickname = The Golden Bear | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|1|21}} | birth_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]] | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|ft=5|in=10}} | nationality = {{USA}} | residence = [[North Palm Beach, Florida]], U.S. | spouse = Barbara Bash
(m. 1960–present) | children = Jack, Steven, Nancy, Gary, Michael | college = [[Ohio State University]] | yearpro = 1961 | retired = 2005 | extour = [[PGA Tour]]
[[Champions Tour]] | prowins = [[List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#Professional wins (117)|117]] | pgawins = [[List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#PGA Tour wins (73)|73]] ([[List of golfers with most PGA Tour wins|3rd all time]]) | eurowins = | auswins = [[List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#PGA Tour of Australasia wins (7)|7]] | champwins = [[List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#Senior PGA Tour wins (10)|10]] | otherwins = [[List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#Other wins (19)|19]] (regular)
[[List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#Other senior wins (8)|8]] (senior) | majorwins = 18 | masters = '''Won''': [[1963 Masters Tournament|1963]], [[1965 Masters Tournament|1965]], [[1966 Masters Tournament|1966]], [[1972 Masters Tournament|1972]], [[1975 Masters Tournament|1975]], [[1986 Masters Tournament|1986]] | usopen = '''Won''': [[1962 U.S. Open (golf)|1962]], [[1967 U.S. Open (golf)|1967]], [[1972 U.S. Open (golf)|1972]], [[1980 U.S. Open (golf)|1980]] | open = '''Won''': [[1966 Open Championship|1966]], [[1970 Open Championship|1970]], [[1978 Open Championship|1978]] | pga = '''Won''': [[1963 PGA Championship|1963]], [[1971 PGA Championship|1971]], [[1973 PGA Championship|1973]], [[1975 PGA Championship|1975]], [[1980 PGA Championship|1980]] | wghofid = jack-nicklaus | wghofyear = 1974 | award1 = [[PGA Tour#Money winners and most wins leaders|PGA Tour
leading money winner]] | year1 = 1964, 1965, 1967, 1971, 1972, 1973, 1975, 1976 | award2 = [[PGA Player of the Year]] | year2 = 1967, 1972, 1973, 1975, 1976 | award3 = [[Bob Jones Award]] | year3 = 1975 | award4 = [[Payne Stewart Award]] | year4 = 2000 | award5 = [[PGA Tour Lifetime Achievement Award|PGA Tour Lifetime
Achievement Award]] | year5 = 2008 | award6 = [[Congressional Gold Medal]] | year6 = 2015 | awardssection = List of career achievements by Jack Nicklaus#Awards }} '''Jack William Nicklaus''' (born January 21, 1940), nicknamed '''The Golden Bear''', is an American retired [[professional golfer]]. Many observers regard him as the greatest golfer of all time.{{cite web|last1=Auclair|first1=T.J.|title=10 Greatest golfers of all time|url=http://www.pga.com/news/golf-buzz/10-greatest-golfers-all-time|website=pga.com|accessdate=May 19, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Chase|first=Chris|date=April 13, 2018|title=Who is the greatest golfer ever: Tiger or Jack?|url=https://ftw.usatoday.com/2018/04/tiger-woods-jack-nickalus|work=[[USA Today]]|location=McLean, Virginia|access-date=July 14, 2018}} During a span of more than 25 years, he won a record 18 [[Men's major golf championships|major championships]] while producing 19 second-place and 9 third-place finishes.{{cite book |last=Spencer |first=Reid |title=The Sporting News selects 50 Greatest Golfers |publisher=The Sporting News |isbn=0-89204-692-9 }} Nicklaus focused on the major championships—[[Masters Tournament]], [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]], [[The Open Championship|Open Championship]] and [[PGA Championship]]—and played a selective schedule of regular [[PGA Tour]] events, yet still finished with 73 victories, third on the all-time list behind [[Sam Snead]] (82) and [[Tiger Woods]] (80). Nicklaus won the [[U.S. Amateur]] in 1959 and 1961 and challenged for the [[1960 U.S. Open (golf)|1960 U.S. Open]], where he finished in second place, two shots behind [[Arnold Palmer]]. Nicklaus turned professional at age 21 toward the end of 1961. He earned his first professional win at the [[1962 U.S. Open (golf)|1962 U.S. Open]], when he defeated Palmer by three shots in a next day 18-hole playoff. This win over Palmer began the on-course rivalry between the two golf superstars. In 1966, Nicklaus won the Masters Tournament for the second year in a row, becoming the first golfer to achieve this distinction, and also won The Open Championship, completing his career slam of major championships.{{cite web|url=http://www.theopen.com/en/History/OpenChampions.aspx#player=Jack+NICKLAUS |title=1966 Jack Nicklaus |publisher=The Open |accessdate=October 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016164928/http://www.theopen.com/en/History/OpenChampions.aspx |archivedate=October 16, 2013 |df= }} At age 26, he became the youngest to do so at the time. He won another Open Championship in 1970. Between 1971 and 1980, he won an additional nine major championships, overtook [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]]' record of 13 majors, and became the first player to complete double and triple career slams of golf's four professional major championships. When Nicklaus claimed his 18th and final major championship at age 46 at the [[1986 Masters Tournament|1986 Masters]], he became the tournament's oldest winner. Nicklaus joined the Senior PGA Tour (now known as the [[PGA Tour Champions]]) when he became eligible in January 1990, and by April 1996 had won 10 tournaments, including eight major championships despite playing a very limited schedule. He continued to play at least some of the four regular Tour majors until 2005, when he made his final appearances at the Masters Tournament and The Open Championship. Nicklaus has also taken part in various other activities, including [[golf course design]], charity work and book writing. He is a member of the [[American Society of Golf Course Architects]] and has helped design courses such as [[Harbour Town Golf Links]]. Nicklaus also runs his own tournament on the PGA Tour, the [[Memorial Tournament]]. His golf course design company is one of the largest in the world. Nicklaus' books vary from instructional to autobiographical, with his ''Golf My Way'' considered one of the best instructional golf books of all time; the video of the same name is the best selling golf instructional to date. ==Early life and amateur golf pursuits== Nicklaus was born in [[Columbus, Ohio]] and grew up in the suburb of [[Upper Arlington, Ohio|Upper Arlington]]. He is of [[German American|German descent]], the son of Helen (Schoener) (1909–2000){{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/12954763/nellie-helen-nicklaus|title=Nellie Helen Schoener Nicklaus (1909–2000)|website=www.findagrave.com}} and Charlie Nicklaus (1913–1970),{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/12954762/louis-charles-nicklaus|title=Louis Charles "Charlie" Nicklaus (1913–1970)|website=www.findagrave.com}} a pharmacist who ran several businesses named Nicklaus Drug Store.{{cite web|url=http://www.golfchannel.com/news/golf-central-blog/know-jack-charlie-and-helen-nicklaus/|title=Know Jack: Charlie and Helen Nicklaus - Golf Channel|work=golfchannel.com}} Charlie was a skilled all-round athlete who had played football for the [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State Buckeyes]] and had gone on to play semi-professional football under an assumed name for the [[Portsmouth Spartans]] (who later became the [[NFL]]'s [[Detroit Lions]]). Charlie had also been a scratch golfer and local [[tennis]] champion in his youth.{{cite book |title=On & Off the Fairway |first1=Jack |last1=Nicklaus |first2=Ken |last2=Bowden |year=1978 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |isbn=978-0671225681}} Charlie Nicklaus died of [[pancreatic cancer]] at age fifty six.{{cite web|url=https://www.everydayhealth.com/pancreatic-cancer/1006/dana-delany-jack-nicklaus-lisa-niemi-swayze-unite-to-raise-awareness-for-pancreatic-cancer.aspx|title=Pancreatic Cancer Action Network Raises Awareness for Pancreatic Cancer|work=everydayhealth.com}} Nicklaus was raised in Upper Arlington and attended [[Upper Arlington High School (Ohio)|Upper Arlington High School]], whose nickname and mascot are coincidentally the Golden Bears. In his senior year, Nicklaus was an honorable mention All-Ohio selection in [[basketball]] as a shooting guard, and he received some recruiting interest from college basketball programs, including Ohio State. During his youth, he also competed successfully in football, baseball, tennis, and track and field.{{cite book |title=The Wicked Game: Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus, Tiger Woods, and the Story of Modern Golf |first=Howard |last=Sounes |authorlink=Howard Sounes |year=2005 |publisher=William Morrow |isbn=978-0-06-051386-3}} Nicklaus took up golf at the age of 10, scoring a 51 at [[Scioto Country Club]] for his first nine holes ever played. Charlie Nicklaus had joined Scioto that same year, returning to golf to help heal a [[volleyball]] injury. Jack Nicklaus was coached at Scioto by club pro [[Jack Grout]], a Texas-developed contemporary of golf greats [[Byron Nelson]] and [[Ben Hogan]]; Grout had played quite successfully on the [[PGA Tour]] and would become Nicklaus' lifelong golf instructor. Nicklaus overcame a [[List of polio survivors|mild case]] of [[polio]] as a 13-year-old.{{cite journal |first=Guy |last=Yocum |title=My Shot: Jack Nicklaus |url=http://www.golfdigest.com/magazine/myshot_gd0404 |magazine=[[Golf Digest]] |date=April 2004 |accessdate=May 22, 2007}} Nicklaus won the first of five straight{{cite book |last1=Nicklaus |first1=Jack |last2=Bowden |first2=Ken |title=Golf My Way |publisher=William Heinemann Ltd |year=1974 |isbn=1-85051-475-5}} Ohio State Junior titles at the age of 12. At 13, he broke 70 at Scioto Country Club for the first time, and became that year's youngest qualifier into the [[U.S. Junior Amateur]], where he survived three match-play rounds. He had earned a handicap of +3 at age 13, the lowest in the Columbus area. Nicklaus won the Tri-State High School Championship (Ohio/[[Kentucky]]/[[Indiana]]) at the age of 14 with a round of 68, and also recorded his first [[hole-in-one]] in tournament play the same year. At 15, Nicklaus shot a 66 at Scioto Country Club, which was the amateur course record, and qualified for his first [[U.S. Amateur]]. He won the [[Ohio Open]] in 1956 at age 16, highlighted by a phenomenal third round of 64, competing against professionals. In all, Nicklaus won 27 events in the Ohio area from age 10 to age 17. In 1957, Nicklaus won the [[International Jaycee Junior Golf Tournament]], having lost the previous year in a playoff. Nicklaus also competed in his first of 44 consecutive [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]s that year, but missed the cut. In 1958 at age 18, he competed in his first PGA Tour event, the Rubber City Open, at [[Akron, Ohio|Akron]], Ohio, tying for 12th place after being just one out of the lead at the 36-hole mark,{{cite news |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B14FE3C5F117B93C7A9178CD85F4C8585F9 |title=Wall's 67 for 132 Keeps Golf Lead; Bolt, Phillips, Nicklaus and Balding Share Second, a Stroke Back, at Akron |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 4, 1958 |agency=UPI}} and made the cut in the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]], tying for 41st place. Nicklaus also won two [[Trans-Mississippi Amateur]]s – in 1958 at [[Prairie Dunes Country Club]] and 1959 at Woodhill Country Club, with final match victories of 9 & 8 and 3 & 2, respectively. Also in 1959, Nicklaus won the [[North and South Amateur]] at [[Pinehurst, North Carolina]] and competed in three additional [[PGA Tour]] events, with his best finish being another 12th place showing at the [[Buick Open]]. While attending [[Ohio State Buckeyes|Ohio State]], he won the [[U.S. Amateur]] twice (1959, 1961), and an [[NCAA Division I Men's Golf Championships|NCAA Championship]] (1961). In the 1959 U.S. Amateur, Nicklaus defeated two-time winner and defending champion [[Charles Coe]] 1-up in the final 36-hole match when he birdied the eighteenth hole.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lztYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XPcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3302,1924641 |newspaper=The Bulletin |location=[[Bend, Oregon]] |agency=United Press International |title=Nicklaus wins National Am; nixes pro life |date=September 21, 1959 |page=3}} This was significant not only because of Coe's proven ability as a player, but also because Nicklaus became the then-youngest champion in the modern era, second only to [[Robert A. Gardner (golfer)|Robert A. Gardner]], who won in 1909. In 1961, Nicklaus became the first player to win the individual title at the NCAA Championship and the U.S. Amateur in the same year. He was followed by [[Phil Mickelson]] (1990), [[Tiger Woods]] (1996), [[Ryan Moore (golfer)|Ryan Moore]] (2004), and [[Bryson DeChambeau]] (2015). Nicklaus also won the NCAA [[Big Ten Conference]] Championship that year with a 72-hole aggregate of 283, while earlier claiming the [[Western Amateur]] in New Orleans. In his second and last U.S. Amateur win in 1961, Nicklaus convincingly defeated [[Dudley Wysong]] 8 & 6 at [[Pebble Beach Golf Links|Pebble Beach]] in the 36-hole championship match. For the week, Nicklaus was 20 strokes under par, including 34 birdies and two eagles. At the [[1960 U.S. Open (golf)|1960 U.S. Open]], twenty-year-old Nicklaus shot a two-under par 282, finishing in second place two strokes behind [[Arnold Palmer]], who won the tournament for the only time with a final round charge of six-under-par 65. This score remains the lowest ever by an amateur in the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]. Nicklaus played the final 36 holes with [[Ben Hogan]], who later remarked that he had just played 36 holes with a kid who should have won by 10 shots. During the final 36 holes, Nicklaus was two-under-par; he had shot every round of the tournament at or below par and was the only entrant to do so. Nicklaus had led by two shots with six holes to play. In 1960, Nicklaus also tied for 13th in the [[Masters Tournament]]. He tied for fourth in the 1961 [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]], three shots behind champion [[Gene Littler]], having played the final 54 holes one under par. Each of these three major championship finishes designated Nicklaus as low amateur. However, Nicklaus' one-under-par 287 tied for seventh in the 1961 [[Masters Tournament]], and was second that year only to [[Charles Coe]]'s low amateur placing, when he tied for second with Arnold Palmer at seven-under par 281, one shot behind champion [[Gary Player]]. Nicklaus represented the United States against Great Britain and Ireland on winning [[Walker Cup]] teams in both 1959 and 1961, decisively winning both of his matches in each contest. On the 1959 trip to Britain, he also made his only attempt at the [[British Amateur]], the world's oldest international amateur event, at [[Royal St George's Golf Club]], reaching the quarterfinal round (top 8). He was also a member of the victorious 1960 U.S. [[Eisenhower Trophy]] team, winning the unofficial individual title by 13 shots over teammate [[Deane Beman]] with a four-round score of 269, a record which still stands; this score was 18 shots lower than [[Ben Hogan]]'s earlier [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] aggregate of 287 at the same site (which had, however, been scored under much tougher conditions).{{cite web|url=http://www.internationalgolffederation.org/2006/men/FactSheet.html|title=2006 World Amateur Championship Fact Sheet|accessdate=March 17, 2007}} For three straight years (1959–1961), Nicklaus was named the world's top amateur golfer by ''[[Golf Digest]]'' magazine. ===College studies and marriage=== Nicklaus attended Ohio State from 1957 to 1961. He majored in pre-[[pharmacy]] and had good grades in his first three years; he intended to follow his father into pharmacy after graduation.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H7BPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5AQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6981,2995885 |newspaper=Ocala Star-Banner |location=[[Ocala, Florida]] |agency=Associated Press |title=Nicklaus says that he won't turn pro |date=August 24, 1959 |page=8}} As his amateur golf achievements mounted, Nicklaus changed his mind on his career path; he switched programs to study [[insurance]]. At that stage, he planned to remain an amateur golfer and earn his living by selling insurance. For a time, he worked in the insurance field while he also attended college.
