Cuts made |- |align=left|[[Masters Tournament]] || 6 || 4 || 2 || 15 || 22 || 29 || 45 || 37 |- |align=left|[[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] || 4 || 4 || 1 || 11 || 18 || 22 || 44 || 35 |- |align=left|[[The Open Championship]] || 3 || 7 || 3 || 16 || 18 || 21 || 38 || 32 |- |align=left|[[PGA Championship]] || 5 || 4 || 3 || 14 || 15 || 23 || 37 || 27 |- !Totals !! 18 !! 19 !! 9 !! 56 !! 73 !! 95 !! 164 !! 131 |} *Most consecutive cuts made – 39 (1969 Masters – 1978 Open) *Longest streak of top-10s – 13 (1973 Masters – 1976 Masters) *At the Open Championship,1966–80, Nicklaus finished 15 consecutive years in the top-6. Specifically 1st (3), 2nd (6), 3rd (2), 4th (2), 5th (1), 6th (1). *At the Masters, 1970–79, Nicklaus finished 10 consecutive years in the top-8. Specifically 1st (2), 2nd (2), 3rd (2), 4th (2), 7th (1), 8th (1). All of the totals above are stand-alone records with the exception of the longest streak of consecutive cuts made in majors at 39 which was equaled by [[Tiger Woods]] (1996–2006) and the longest streak of top-10s in majors which is held by [[Ben Hogan]] with 18 between 1948 and 1956. ===Senior major championships=== ====Wins (8)==== {|class="sortable wikitable" !Year!!Championship!!Winning score!!Margin!!Runner(s)-up |- style="background:#d0f0c0;" | 1990 ||[[The Tradition at Desert Mountain]] ||−10 (71-67-68=206) ||4 strokes ||{{Flagicon|South Africa|1928}} [[Gary Player]] |- style="background:#ff9;" | 1990 ||[[Mazda Senior Tournament Players Championship]] ||−27 (65-68-64-64=261) ||6 strokes ||{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Lee Trevino]] |- style="background:#d0f0c0;" | 1991 ||[[The Tradition at Desert Mountain]] (2) ||−11 (71-73-66-67=277) ||1 stroke ||{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Jim Colbert]], {{Flagicon|USA}} [[Jim Dent]], {{Flagicon|USA}} [[Phil Rodgers]] |- style="background:thistle;" | 1991 ||[[PGA Seniors' Championship]] ||−17 (66-66-69-70=271) ||6 strokes ||{{Flagicon|AUS}} [[Bruce Crampton]] |- style="background:#fbceb1;" | 1991 ||[[U.S. Senior Open]] ||+2 (72-69-70-71=282) ||Playoff1||{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Juan "Chi-Chi" Rodríguez|Chi-Chi Rodríguez]] |- style="background:#fbceb1;" | 1993 ||[[U.S. Senior Open]] (2) ||−6 (68-73-67-70=278) ||1 stroke ||{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Tom Weiskopf]] |- style="background:#d0f0c0;" | 1995 ||[[The Tradition]] (3) ||−12 (69-71-69-67=276) ||Playoff2||{{Flagicon|JPN}} [[Isao Aoki]] |- style="background:#d0f0c0;" | 1996 ||[[The Tradition]] (4) ||−16 (68-74-65-65=272) ||3 strokes ||{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Hale Irwin]] |} 1 In an 18-hole playoff, Nicklaus shot a (65) to Rodríguez's (69). ====Results timeline==== {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; revision.comment: As the person is still alive, 'was' was changed to 'is' with the addition of 'former' to clarify that he is not active in the Iranian political scenes any more.
revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Jalaleddin Farsi | image = JalaleddinFarsi.png | birth_date = {{circa}} {{birth year and age|1935}} | birth_place = [[Mashhad]], [[Iran]] | death_date = | death_place = | office1 = Member of [[Iranian Parliament]] | term_start1 = 28 May 1984 | term_end1 = 28 May 1988 | constituency1 = [[Tehran, Rey, Shemiranat and Eslamshahr (electoral district)|Tehran, Rey and Shemiranat]] | majority1 = 1,260,779 (54.6%) | office2 = Member of [[Assembly of Experts for Constitution]] | term_start2 = 15 August 1979 | term_end2 = 15 November 1979 |constituency2 = [[Khorasan Province]] | majority2 = 660,001 (62.1%) | party = [[Islamic Republican Party]] | otherparty = [[Islamic Coalition Party]] | occupation = | nationality = [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] }} '''Jaleleddin Farsi''' ({{lang-fa|جلال‌الدین فارسی}}) is an Iranian former politician who served as a member of the [[Iranian Parliament|parliament]] from 1984 to 1988. He was also elected to the 73-man [[Assembly of Experts for Constitution]] responsible for drafting the [[Constitution of Iran|constitution]] in 1979. Farsi belonged to the [[Islamic Republican Party]]'s radical faction{{cite book|author=Sepehr Zabir|title=The Left in Contemporary Iran (RLE Iran D)|date=2012|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-136-81263-7|page=104}} and was its candidate for president in the [[Iranian presidential election, 1980|1980 election]], however he was replaced by [[Hassan Habibi]] after his [[Afghan]] origin was revealed (according to Article 115 of the constitution, president must be an Iranian citizen with Iranian origin).{{cite book|last=Adelkhah|first=Fariba|date=2015|series=Iranian Studies|volume=27|title=The Thousand and One Borders of Iran: Travel and Identity|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1317418972|page=44}} Before the [[Iranian Revolution]], Farsi was trained in guerilla techniques in [[Lebanon]]. He was a senior [[Islamic Coalition Party|Islamic Coalition]] member and maintained ties to [[Fada'iyan-e Islam]].{{cite book|author=Baqer Moin|title=Khomeini: Life of the Ayatollah|year=1999|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-85043-128-2|pages=233}} ==Murder case== In 1992, Farsi killed a farmer in [[Taleqan]] during an argument. Four years later he was reportedly sentenced to the death penalty by the court of law. The case has never been cleared up.{{citation|title=Iranian politician condemned to death|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1996/02/01/Iranian-politician-condemned-to-death/1599823150800/|date=1 February 1996|access-date=2 November 2017|work=United Press International}} ==References== * [http://www.majlesekhobregan.ir/fa/MohagheghView.html?ItemID=695 Assembly of Experts for Constitution Profile] {{reflist}} {{Iran-politician-stub}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-new|reason=Inaugural presidential election}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Islamic Republican Party]] nominee for [[President of Iran]]|years=[[Iranian presidential election, 1980|1980]]
(withdrew)}} {{s-aft|after=[[Hassan Habibi]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Farsi, Jalaleddin}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Islamic Republican Party politicians]] [[Category:People of the Iranian Revolution]] [[Category:Iranian people of Afghan descent]] [[Category:Islamic Coalition Party politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Assembly of Experts for Constitution]]

Perbandingan Dengan TKI di Luar Negeri|accessdate=11 May 2018}} |region15 = {{Flagcountry|Australia}} |pop15 = 12,000{{cn|date=July 2017}} |region16 = {{Flagcountry|New Caledonia}} |pop16 = |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} |region17 = {{Flagcountry|French Guiana}} |pop17 = 2,800{{cn|date=July 2017}} |region18 = {{Flagcountry|Germany}} |pop18 = 2,400{{cn|date=July 2017}} |langs = {{align|left| * [[Javanese language|Javanese]] ([[Mataram Sultanate|Mataram]], [[Cirebonese]], [[Osing dialect|Osing]], [[Tenggerese dialect|Tenggerese]], [[Bawean|Boyanese]], [[Samin people|Samin]], [[Kampung Naga|Naganese]], [[Banyumasan dialect|Banyumasan]], [[Arekan dialect|Arekan]], [[Kedu dialect|Kedu]], etc.) * [[Dutch language|Dutch]] (used only by those living in [[Netherlands]] and [[Suriname]]) * [[Malay language|Malay]] (used only by those living outside their traditional areas in the [[Malay Archipelago]] for formal & commercial purposes, as a home medium vernacular amongst younger generations and/or to communicate with non-Javanese populations in the region, also used for those living abroad; its [[Indonesian language|Indonesian variant]] used only by those living in Indonesia) * [[Cantonese dialect|Cantonese]] (used only by those living in [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]]) * [[French language|French]] (used only by those living in [[New Caledonia]]) * [[English language|English]] (used only by many of those living abroad, especially in the countries where English is an official language) }} |rels = Historically: [[Hinduism in Indonesia#Javanese Hinduism|Javanese Hinduism]], [[Mahayana|Mahayana Buddhism]],[https://lifestyle.kompas.com/read/2012/02/18/04155621/kisah.mataram.di.poros.kedu-prambanan "Kisah Mataram di Poros Kedu-Prambanan"]. Kompas.com (in Indonesian).[https://regional.kompas.com/read/2017/11/09/11181311/buddha-dharma-dan-cinta-kasih "Buddha, Dharma, dan Cinta Kasih"]. Kompas.com (in Indonesian). [[Nature worship]], and [[Animism]]
Predominantly: [[Islam]] (mostly [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]])
Traditionally: [[Kejawen|Javanism]]
Sizable minority: [[Protestantism]], [[Roman Catholicism]], [[Shaivism|Shaivite Hinduism]], [[Vajrayana|Vajrayana Buddhism]], and [[Confucianism]] |related-c = Other [[Ethnic groups in Indonesia|Indonesian ethnic groups]]: [[Balinese people|Balinese]], [[Indo people]], [[Madurese people|Madurese]], [[Sasak people|Sasak]], [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]], [[Chinese Indonesians|Tionghoa]] }} {{Javanese script}} The '''Javanese''' (''Ngoko'' [[Javanese script|Javanese]]: {{Jav|ꦮꦺꦴꦁꦗꦮ}},Kamus Pepak Basa Jawa, Sudaryanto/Pranowo, 2001, #1359 ''Madya'' [[Javanese script|Javanese]]: {{Jav|ꦠꦶꦪꦁꦗꦮꦶ}},See: [[Javanese language#Politeness|Javanese language: Politeness]] ''Krama'' [[Javanese script|Javanese]]: {{Jav|ꦥꦿꦶꦪꦤ꧀ꦠꦸꦤ꧀ꦗꦮꦶ}}, ''Ngoko'' [[Javanese language|Gêdrìk]]: '''wòng Jåwå''', ''Madya'' [[Javanese language|Gêdrìk]]: '''tiyang Jawi''', ''Krama'' [[Javanese language|Gêdrìk]]: '''priyantun Jawi''', [[Malay language|Malay]]: '''''suku''''' / '''''orang Jawa'''''){{Cite book | last = Harjawiyana | first = Haryana | author2 = Theodorus Supriya, | title = Kamus unggah-ungguh basa Jawa | publisher = Kanisius | year = 2001 | pages = 185 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-NOupFY-YTAC&pg=PA185 | isbn = 978-979-672-991-3 }} are an [[ethnic group]] native to the [[Indonesia]]n island of [[Java]]. With approximately 100 million people{{cn|date=November 2018}} ({{As of|2011|lc=on}}), they form the largest [[Ethnic groups in Indonesia|ethnic group in Indonesia]]. They are predominantly located in the [[Central Java|central]] to [[East Java|eastern]] parts of the island. There are also significant numbers of people of Javanese descent in most [[provinces of Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], [[Suriname]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[Netherlands]]. The '''Javanese''' ethnic group has many sub-groups, such as the [[Mataram Sultanate|Mataram]], [[Cirebonese]], [[Osing people|Osing]], [[Tenggerese people|Tenggerese]], [[Samin people|Samin]], [[Kampung Naga|Naganese]], [[Banyumasan people|Banyumasan]], etc.{{cite web|url=http://sp2010.bps.go.id/files/ebook/kewarganegaraan%20penduduk%20indonesia/index.html|title=Publication Name:|publisher=}} A majority of the Javanese people identify themselves as [[Muslim]]s, with a minority identifying as [[Christians]] and [[Hindu]]s. However, Javanese civilization has been influenced by more than a millennium of interactions between the native animism [[Kejawen]] and the Indian [[Hindu]]—[[Buddhist]] culture, and this influence is still visible in Javanese history, culture, traditions, and art forms. With a sizeable global population, the Javanese are considered significant as they are the [[List of contemporary ethnic groups|fourth largest ethnic group among Muslims]], in the world, after the [[Arabs]],Margaret Kleffner Nydell [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNoiieefqAcC&printsec Understanding Arabs: A Guide For Modern Times], Intercultural Press, 2005, {{ISBN|1931930252}}, page xxiii, 14 [[Bengali Muslims|Bengalis]]roughly 170 million in [[Bangladesh]] and 130 million in the [[Republic of India]] ([[CIA Factbook]] 2014 estimates, numbers subject to rapid population growth); about 10 million [[Bangladeshis in the Middle East]], 1 million [[Bengalis in Pakistan]], 5 million [[British Bangladeshi]]. and [[Punjabi Muslims|Punjabis]].{{cite book|last=Gandhi|first=Rajmohan|title=Punjab: A History from Aurangzeb to Mountbatten|year=2013|page=1|publisher=Aleph Book Company|location=New Delhi, India, Urbana, [[Illinois]]|isbn=978-93-83064-41-0}} ==History== {{Other uses|Javanese historical texts}} Like most Indonesian ethnic groups, including the [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]] of [[West Java]], the Javanese are of [[Austronesian people|Austronesian]] origins whose ancestors are thought to have originated in [[Taiwan]], and migrated through [[the Philippines]]{{Cite book | last = Spiller | first = Henry | title = Gamelan music of Indonesia | publisher = Taylor & Francis | year = 2008 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2L2Z2nYd_QsC | isbn = 978-0-415-96067-0 }} to reach Java between 1,500BC and 1,000BC.Taylor (2003), p. 7. However, according to recent genetic study, Javanese together with Sundanese and Balinese has almost equal ratio of genetic marker shared between [[Austronesian]] and [[Austroasiatic]] heritages.{{cite web | title = Pemetaan Genetika Manusia Indonesia | work = Kompas.com | url = http://assets.kompas.com/data/photo/2015/10/12/1113035menyusuri-jejak-leluhur780x390.JPG | language = Indonesian }} === Ancient Javanese kingdoms and empires === [[File:Javanese Dance Ramayana Shinta 2.jpg|thumb|left|Javanese adapted many aspects of Indian culture, such as the [[Ramayana]] epic.]] [[Hinduism|Hindu]] and [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] influences arrived through trade contacts with the [[Indian subcontinent]].{{Cite book | last = Miksic | first = John |author2=Marcello Tranchini |author3=Anita Tranchini | title = Borobudur: Golden Tales of the Buddhas | publisher = Tuttle Publishing | year = 1996 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MVoZGA2yfywC | isbn = 978-0-945971-90-0 }} Hindu and Buddhist - traders and visitors, arrived in the 5th century. The Hindu, Buddhist and Javanese faiths blended into a unique local philosophy. The cradle of Javanese culture is commonly described as being in [[Kedu Plain|Kedu]] and [[Kewu Plain]] in the fertile slopes of [[Mount Merapi]] as the heart of the [[Medang Kingdom|Medang i Bhumi Mataram kingdom]].{{Cite book | last = Tarling | first = Nicholas | title = Cambridge history of South East Asia: From early times to c.1500 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1999 | pages = 203 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0b-6wpalR40C | isbn = 978-0-521-66369-4 }} The earliest [[Sanjaya dynasty|Sanjaya]] and [[Sailendra]] dynasties had their power base there.{{rp|238–239}} The centre of Javanese culture and politics was moved towards the eastern part of the island when [[Mpu Sindok]] (r. 929-947) moved the capital of the kingdoms eastward to the valleys of the [[Brantas River]] in the 10th century CE. The move was most likely caused by the [[volcanic eruption]] of [[Mount Merapi|Merapi]] and/or invasion from [[Srivijaya]].{{rp|238–239}} The major spread of Javanese influence occurred under King [[Kertanegara of Singhasari]] in the late 13th century. The expansionist king launched several major expeditions to Madura, Bali in 1284, Borneo{{when|date=May 2013}} and [[Pamalayu expedition|most importantly to Sumatra]] in 1275.{{Cite book | last = Spuler | first = Bertold |author2=F.R.C. Bagley | title = The Muslim world: a historical survey, Part 4 | publisher = Brill Archive | pages = 252 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VNgUAAAAIAAJ | isbn = 978-90-04-06196-5 | date = 31 December 1981 }} Following the defeat of the [[Melayu Kingdom]], [[Singhasari]] controlled trade in the [[Strait of Malacca]]. Singhasari dominance was cut short in 1292 by Kediri's rebellion under [[Jayakatwang]], killing Kertanegara. However, Jayakatwang's reign as king of Java soon ended as he was defeated by Kertanegara's son-in-law, [[Raden Wijaya]] with the help of [[Mongol invasion of Java|invading Mongol troops]] in March 1293. [[Raden Wijaya]] would later establish [[Majapahit]] near the delta of the Brantas River in modern-day [[Mojokerto]], [[East Java]]. Kertanegara policies were later continued by the [[Majapahit]]s under King [[Hayam Wuruk]] and his minister [[Gajah Mada]]. Various kingdoms of Java were actively involved in the [[spice]] trade in the sea route of the [[Silk Road]]. Although not major spice producers, these kingdoms were able to stockpile spice by trading for it with [[rice]], of which Java was a major producer.{{Cite book | author = Marshall Cavendish Corporation | title = World and Its Peoples: Indonesia and East Timor | publisher = Marshall Cavendish | year = 2007 | pages = 1333 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zFKcQ8_dS00C | isbn = 978-0-7614-7643-6 }} Majapahit is usually regarded as the greatest of these kingdoms. It was both an agrarian and a maritime power, combining wet-rice cultivation and foreign trade. The ruin of their capital can be found in [[Trowulan]]. === Javanese sultanates === [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Schildering voorstellende de moord op kapitein Tack in Kartasura TMnr H-796.jpg|thumb|right|Sultan [[Amangkurat II of Mataram]] (upper right) watching warlord Untung Surapati fighting Captain Tack of the [[Dutch East India Company]] (VOC). ca 1684 AD.]] [[Islam]] gained its foothold in port towns on Java's northern coast such as [[Gresik]], Ampel Denta ([[Surabaya]]), Tuban, Demak and [[Kudus, Kudus|Kudus]]. The spread and proselytising of Islam among the Javanese was traditionally credited to [[Wali Sanga|Wali Songo]].{{cite book | last =Ricklefs | first =M.C. | authorlink = | title =A History of Modern Indonesia since c.1300, 2nd Edition | publisher =MacMillan | year =1991 | location =London | pages =9–10. | isbn = 0-333-57689-6}} Java underwent major changes as [[Islam]] spread. Following succession disputes and civil wars, Majapahit power collapsed. After this collapse, its various dependencies and vassals broke free.{{Cite book | last = Muljana | first = Slamet | authorlink = | title = Runtuhnya kerajaan Hindu-Jawa dan timbulnya negara-negara Islam di Nusantara | publisher = LKiS | year = 2005 | location = Yogyakarta, Indonesia | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = 979-8451-16-3}} The [[Sultanate of Demak]] became the new strongest power, gaining supremacy among city-states on the northern coast of Java. {{Cite book | last = Pires | first = Tomé | authorlink = | title = The Suma oriental of Tome Pires: an account of the East | publisher = Asian Educational Services | year = 1990 | location = New Delhi | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=h82D-Y0E3TwC&pg=PA184&dq=demak&cd=5#v=onepage&q=demak&f=false | doi = | isbn = 81-206-0535-7 }} Aside from its power over Javanese city-states, it also gained overlordship of the ports of [[Jambi]] and [[Palembang]] in eastern Sumatra. Demak played a major role in opposing the newly arrived colonial power, the [[Portugal|Portuguese]]. Demak twice attacked the Portuguese following their capture of [[Malacca]]. They also attacked [[Luso Sundanese padrão|the allied forces]] of the Portuguese and the [[Sunda Kingdom]], establishing in the process the [[Sultanate of Banten]]. Demak was succeeded by the [[Kingdom of Pajang]] and finally the [[Mataram Sultanate|Sultanate of Mataram]]. The centre of power moved from coastal Demak, to Pajang in Blora, and later further inland to Mataram lands in [[Kotagede]], near present-day [[Yogyakarta]]. The Mataram Sultanate reached its peak of power and influence during the reign of [[Sultan Agung of Mataram|Sultan Agung Hanyokrokusumo]] between 1613 and 1645. === Colonial Java === [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM 'Het veertig-jarig regeringsjubileum van Soesoehoenan Pakoe Boewono X van Surakarta in de stoet lopen serimpi's mee' TMnr 10001563.jpg|thumb|right|A Javanese courtly ceremony at Keraton Surakarta in 1932.]] In 1619 the [[Dutch people|Dutch]] established their trading headquarter in [[Jakarta|Batavia]]. Java slowly fell to the [[Dutch East India Company]], which would also eventually control most of [[Maritime Southeast Asia]]. The internal intrigue and war of succession, in addition to Dutch interference, caused the Mataram Sultanate to break up into [[Surakarta Sunanate|Surakarta]] and [[Yogyakarta Sultanate|Yogyakarta]]. The further separation of the Javanese realm was marked by the establishment of the [[Mangkunegaran]] and [[Pakualaman]] princedom. Although the real political power in those days actually lay with the colonial Dutch, the Javanese kings, in their [[keraton]]s, still held prestige as the supposed power centre of the Javanese realm, especially in and around Surakarta and Yogyakarta. Dutch rule was briefly interrupted by [[United Kingdom|British]] rule in the early 19th century. While short, the British administration led by [[Stamford Raffles]] was significant, and included the re-discovery of [[Borobudur]]. Conflict with foreign rule was exemplified by the [[Java War]] between 1825 and 1830, and the leadership of Prince [[Diponegoro]]. Like the rest of the [[Dutch East Indies]], Java was captured by the [[Empire of Japan]] during [[World War II]]. With Japan's defeat, independence was proclaimed in the new [[Republic of Indonesia]]. ===Republic of Indonesia=== When the Indonesian independence was proclaimed on 17 August 1945, the last sovereign Javanese monarchies, represented by the Sri Sultan of [[Yogyakarta Sultanate|Yogyakarta]], the Sunanate of [[Surakarta Sunanate|Surakarta]] and Prince of Mangkunegara declared that they would become part of the Republic of Indonesia. Yogyakarta and Pakualam were later united to form the Yogyakarta Special Region. The Sri sultan became Governor of Yogyakarta, and the Prince of Pakualaman became vice-governor; both were responsible to the President of Indonesia. The Special Region of Yogyakarta was created after the war of independence ended and formalised on 3 August 1950. Surakarta was later absorbed as part of the Central Java province. ==Culture== {{main article|Javanese culture}} {{See also|Javanese dance|Javanisation}} [[File:Wayang Performance.jpg|thumb|right|Javanese cultural expressions, such as [[wayang]] and [[gamelan]] are often used to promote the excellence of Javanese culture.]] The [[Javanese culture]] is one of the oldest civilisations and has flourished in Indonesia. It has gradually absorbed various elements and influences from other cultures, including native reverence for ancestral and natural spirits, [[Hindu]] and [[Buddhist]] dharmic civilisation, Islamic values, and to a lesser extent, Christianity, Western philosophy and modern ideas. Nevertheless, Javanese culture — especially in the Javanese cultural heartland; those of highly polished aristocratic culture of the ''[[keraton]]s'' in [[Yogyakarta]] and [[Surakarta]] — demonstrates some specific traits, such as particular concern with elegance and refinement (Javanese: ''alus''), subtlety, politeness, courtesy, indirectness, emotional restraint and consciousness to one's social stature. Javanese culture values harmony and social order highly, and abhors direct conflicts and disagreements. These Javanese values are often promoted through Javanese cultural expressions, such as [[Javanese dance]], [[gamelan]], [[wayang]] and [[batik]]. It is also reinforced through adherence to Javanese ''adat'' (traditional rules) in ceremonies, such as ''[[Slametan]], [[Satu Suro]]'', Javanese weddings and ''[[Naloni Mitoni]]''. However, the culture of ''pesisiran'' of Javanese north coast and in Eastern Java demonstrates some slightly different traits. They tend to be more open to new and foreign ideas, more egalitarian, and less conscious of one's social stature. Some of these northern settlements — such as Demak, Kudus, Tuban, Gresik and Ampel in Surabaya — have become more overtly Islamic, traditionally because these port towns are among the earliest places that Islamic teachings gained foothold in Java. [[File:Gamelan Player 1.JPG|thumb|right|[[Gamelan]] is one of Javanese cultural expression that demonstrate refinement.]] Javanese culture is traditionally centred in the [[Central Java]], [[Yogyakarta]] and [[East Java]] provinces of Indonesia. Due to various migrations, it can also be found in other parts of the world, such as [[Suriname]] (where 15% of the population are of Javanese descent), the broader Indonesian archipelago region,{{Cite book | last = Shucker | first = M. A. M. | title = Muslims of Sri Lanka: avenues to antiquity | publisher = Jamiah Naleemia Inst. | year = 1986 | oclc = 15406023}} [[Cape Malay]],{{Cite book | last = Williams | first = Faldela | title = Cape Malay Cookbook | publisher = Struik | year = 1988 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=twILUiq8138C | isbn = 978-1-86825-560-3}} [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], [[Netherlands]] and other countries. The migrants bring with them various aspect of Javanese cultures such as Gamelan music, traditional dances{{Cite book | last = Matusky | first = Patricia Ann |author2=Sooi Beng Tan | title = The music of Malaysia: the classical, folk, and syncretic traditions | publisher = Ashgate Publishing | year = 2004 | pages = 107 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=x06nBdEkAOMC | isbn = 978-0-7546-0831-8 }} and the art of [[Wayang kulit]] shadow play.{{Cite book | last = Osnes | first = Beth | title = The Shadow Puppet Theatre of Malaysia: A Study of Wayang Kulit with Performance Scripts and Puppet Designs | publisher = McFarland | year = 2010 | pages = 26 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ykQlV616gX4C | isbn = 978-0-7864-4838-8 }} The migration of Javanese people westward has created a coastal Javanese culture in West Java distinct from the inland [[Sundanese people|Sundanese culture]]. ===Language=== {{main article|Javanese language}} {{See also|Javanese script|Javanese (Unicode block)}} [[File:Hanacaraka-jawa.svg|thumb|left|[[Javanese alphabet]].]] [[Javanese language|Javanese]] is a member of the [[Austronesian languages|Austronesian]] family of languages and is closely related to, but distinct from, other [[languages of Indonesia]].{{Cite book | last = Robson | first = Stuart | authorlink = |author2=Singgih Wibisono | title = Javanese English dictionary | publisher = Tuttle Publishing | year = 2002 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=SbiKu52WZr0C | doi = | isbn = 978-0-7946-0000-6 }} It is notable for its great number of nearly ubiquitous [[Sanskrit]] loans, found especially in literary Javanese.{{Cite book | last = Marr | first = David G. | authorlink = |author2=Anthony Crothers Milner | title = Southeast Asia in the 9th to 14th centuries | publisher = Institute of Southeast Asian Studies | year = 1986 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Lon7gmj040MC | doi = | isbn = 978-9971-988-39-5 }} This is due to the long history of Hindu and Buddhist influences in Java. Most Javanese in Indonesia are [[bilingual]], being fluent in [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] and Javanese.{{Cite book | last = Errington | first = James Joseph | authorlink = | title = Shifting languages: interaction and identity in Javanese Indonesia | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1998 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xyKs6thiNIwC | doi = | isbn = 978-0-521-63448-9 }} In a public poll held [[circa]]-1990, approximately 12% of Javanese used [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], around 18% used both Javanese and Indonesian, and the rest used Javanese exclusively. The Javanese language was formerly written with a script descended from the [[Brahmi script]], natively known as ''Hanacaraka'' or ''Carakan''. Upon Indonesian independence it was replaced with a form of the [[Latin alphabet]]. [[File:Javanese commoner and Javanese warrior.jpg|thumb|270x270px|An image of Javanese commoner and Javanese warrior, from Homann's map of Batavia, 1733.]] While Javanese was not made an [[official language]] of Indonesia, it has the status of regional language for communication in the Javanese-majority regions. The language also can be viewed as an ethnic language because it is one of the defining characteristics of the Javanese ethnic identity. ===Literature and philosophy=== {{main article|Javanese literature|Javanese poetry}} Javanese intellectuals, writers, poets and men of letters are known for their ability to formulate ideas and creating [[idiom]]s for high cultural purpose, through stringing words to express a deeper philosophical meanings. Several philosophical idioms sprung from Javanese classical literature, [[Javanese historical texts]] and oral traditions, and have spread into several media and promoted as popular [[motto]]s. For example, ''"[[Bhinneka Tunggal Ika]]"'', used as the national motto of the [[Republic of Indonesia]], ''"Gemah Ripah Loh Jinawi, Toto Tentrem Kerto Raharjo"'', ''"Jer Basuki Mawa Bea"'', ''"Rawe-Rawe rantas, Malang-Malang putung"'' and ''"[[Tut Wuri Handayani]]"''.{{Cite book | last = Soeseno | first = Ki Nardjoko | authorlink = | title = Falsafah Jawa Soeharto & Jokowi | publisher = Araska | year = 2014 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = 978-602-7733-82-4 }} ===Social structure=== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Portret van een Javaanse vorst of notabele met twee bedienden TMnr 60004903.jpg|upright|thumb|Javanese ''priyayi'' (aristocrat) and servants, {{circa}} 1865.]] The [[United States|American]] [[Anthropology|anthropologist]] [[Clifford Geertz]] divided in the 1960s the Javanese community into three ''aliran'' or "streams": [[santri]], [[abangan]] and [[priyayi]]. According to him, the Santri followed an orthodox interpretation [[Islam]], the abangan followed a syncretic form of Islam that mixed Hindu and animist elements (often termed ''[[Kejawen]]''), and the priyayi were the nobility.{{cite book | last = McDonald | first = Hamish | title = Suharto's Indonesia | publisher = Fontana | year = 1980 | location = Melbourne | pages = 9–10 | isbn = 0-00-635721-0}} The Geertz opinion is often opposed today because he mixed the social groups with belief groups. It was also difficult to apply this social categorisation in classing outsiders, for example other non-[[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] Indonesians such as persons of [[Arab Indonesian|Arab]], [[Chinese Indonesian|Chinese]] and [[India]]n descent. Social stratification is much less rigid in northern coast area. ===Religion=== {{see also|Religion in Indonesia}} {{bar box | width = 300px | barwidth = 200px | float = right | title = Distribution of religious affiliation, 2000{{sfn|Ananta|Arifin|Bakhtiar|2008|p=30}} | bars = {{bar percent|Muslims|green|95.38}} {{bar percent|Christians|blue|1.70}} {{bar percent|Hindus|red|1.50}} {{bar percent|Buddhists|orange|1.22}} {{bar percent|Others|yellow|0.20}} | caption = Javanese population = 95,217,022 }} {{main article|Kebatinan|Javanese sacred places}} Today, most Javanese follow [[Islam]] as their religion,{{Cite book | last = Geertz | first = Clifford | authorlink = | title = The religion of Java | publisher = University of Chicago Press | year = 1976 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-SYM4PW-YAgC | doi = | isbn = 978-0-226-28510-8 }} while only 5-10 percent of Javanese follow orthodox Islamic traditions.{{cite web|url=http://www.philtar.ac.uk/encyclopedia/indon/java.html|title=Javanese Religion|website=www.philtar.ac.uk}} Orthodox Muslims are most common in the northern coast bordering the [[Java Sea]], where Islam was first brought to the island. Islam first came in contact with Java during the Majapahit period, when they traded or made tributary relations with various states like Perlak and [[Samudra Pasai]] in modern-day [[Aceh]].{{Cite book | last =Wink | first = André | title = Indo-Islamic society, 14th-15th centuries | publisher = BRILL | year = 2004 | pages = 217 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nyYslywJUE8C | isbn = 978-90-0413561-1}} A minority of Javanese also follow [[Christianity]] ([[Protestantism]] and [[Catholicism]]), which are concentrated in [[Central Java]] (particularly [[Surakarta]], [[Magelang]] and [[Yogyakarta]] for Catholicism). Native Christian churches such as the [[Javanese Christian Church|Gereja Kristen Jawa]] also exist. On a smaller scale, [[Buddhism in Indonesia|Buddhism]] and [[Hinduism in Indonesia|Hinduism]] are also found in the Javanese community. The Javanese of the [[Tenggerese people|Tengger tribe]] continue to practice Javanese-Hindu today, and live in villages on the slope of [[Mount Bromo]].{{Cite book | last = Beatty | first = Andrew | title = Varieties of Javanese religion: an anthropological account | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1999 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=axMY8TFSBywC | isbn = 978-0-521-62473-2 }} ''Kebatinan'', also called ''Kejawen'',{{sfn|Gin|2004|p=719}} ''Agama Jawa''{{sfn|Caldarola|1982|p=501}} and ''[[Aliran kepercayaan|Kepercayaan]]''{{sfn|Hooker|1988|p=196}} is a [[Java]]nese religious tradition, consisting of an amalgam of [[animism|animistic]], [[Hindu]]-[[Buddhist]], and [[Islamic]], especially [[Sufi]], beliefs and practices. It is rooted in Javanese history and religiosity, [[Syncretism|syncretising]] aspects of different religions. ===Calendar=== {{main article|Javanese calendar}} The Javanese [[calendar]] is used by the Javanese people concurrently with two other calendars, the [[Gregorian calendar]] and the [[Islamic calendar]]. The Gregorian calendar is the official calendar of Indonesia, while the Islamic calendar is used by Muslims and Indonesian government for religious worship and deciding relevant [[Islamic holidays]]. The Javanese calendar is presently used mostly for cultural events (such as [[Satu Sura|Siji Surå]]). The Javanese calendar system is currently a lunar calendar adopted by [[Sultan Agung]] in 1633, based on the Islamic calendar. Previously, Javanese people used a solar system based on the [[Hindu calendar]]. Unlike many other calendars, the Javanese calendar uses a 5-day week known as the ''[[Javanese calendar#Five-day week (Pasaran)|Pasaran]]'' cycle. This is still in use today and is superimposed with 7-day week of the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Islamic calendar]] to become what is known as the 35-day [[Javanese calendar#Wetonan cycle|Wetonan cycle]]. ===Architecture=== {{main article|Javanese traditional house}} [[File:RUMAHJAWA 1.jpg|thumb|right|Traditional Javanese house.]] Throughout their long history, the Javanese have produced many important buildings, ranging from Hindu monuments, Buddhist [[stupa]], mortuary temples, palace complexes, and mosques. Two important religious monuments are the Hindu temple of [[Prambanan]] and the Buddhist temple of [[Borobudur]]. Both of them are 9th century temples and [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]]s. Both are located near [[Yogyakarta]] in the slope of Mount Merapi. Meanwhile, examples of secular buildings can be seen in the ruins of the former capital city of the [[Majapahit]] Kingdom (14th to 16th century AD) in [[Trowulan]], [[East Java]]. The complex covers an area of 11 km x 9 km. It consists of various brick buildings, a canal ranging from 20 to 40 meters wide, purification pools, temples and iconic split gates.{{Cite web | last = Ministry of Culture and Tourism of the Republic of Indonesia | authorlink = | title = Trowulan - Former Capital City of Majapahit Kingdom | publisher = United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) World Heritage Convention | date = 6 October 2009 | url = http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5466/ | accessdate = }} The capital complex is currently being considered as a candidate for becoming a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. Traditional Javanese buildings can be identified by their trapezoid shaped roofs supported by wooden pillars.{{Cite book | last = Karaton Ngayogyakarta Hadiningrat | first = | authorlink = Sultanate of Yogyakarta | title = Kraton Jogja: the history and cultural heritage | publisher = Kraton Yogyakarta, Indonesia Marketing Association | year = 2002 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=t49wAAAAMAAJ | isbn = 978-979-969060-9 | id = {{ISBN|979-96906-0-9}} }} Another common feature in Javanese buildings are ''[[pendopo]]'', pavilions with open-sides and four large pillars. The pillars and other parts of the buildings can be richly [[wood carving|carved]]. This architecture style can be found at ''[[Kraton (Indonesia)|kraton]]'', or palaces, of the Sultanates of [[Yogyakarta]] (palaces of [[Hamengkubuwono]] and [[Pakualaman]]) and [[Surakarta]] (palaces of [[Pakubuwono]] and [[Mangkunegaran]]).{{Cite book | last = Eliot | first = Joshua |author2=Liz Capaldi |author3=Jane Bickersteth | title = Indonesia handbook, Volume 3 | publisher = Footprint Travel Guides | year = 2001 | pages = 303 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ktv0_me9x2UC&pg=PA303 | isbn = 978-1-900949-51-4 | id = {{ISBN|1-900949-51-2}} }} Traditional [[mosque]]s in Java maintain a distinctive Javanese style. The ''pendopo'' model is used as the main feature of mosques as prayer halls. A trapezoidal roof is used instead of the more typically Muslim [[dome]]. These roofs are often multi-tiered and tiled.{{Cite book | last = Kusno | first = Abidin | title = Behind the postcolonial: architecture, urban space, and political cultures in Indonesia | publisher = Routledge | year = 2000 | pages = 3 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=DVPS0wh9Y2gC&pg=PA3 | isbn = }} In addition to not using domes, traditional Javanese mosques also often lack [[minaret]]s.{{Cite book | last = Singh | first = Nagendra Kr | title = International encyclopaedia of Islamic dynasties | publisher = Anmol Publications | year = 2002 | pages = 148 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6onixjsS0iAC&pg=PA148 | isbn =978-81-2610403-1 | id ={{ISBN|81-261-0403-1}} }} The split gate from earlier Hindu-Buddhist period is still used in many mosques and public buildings in Java. Some notable examples of mosques using traditional Javanese architecture include the [[Agung Demak Mosque]], the [[Menara Kudus Mosque]] and the Grand Mosque of [[Banten]]. The Kudus Mosque is also of note because it incorporates Hindu-style stone architecture. ===Cuisine=== {{main article|Javanese cuisine}} [[File:Javanese Cuisine, Djogdja.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Example of Javanese cuisine. Clockwise: fried [[tempeh]], ''[[Gnetum gnemon|mlinjo]]'' [[Krupuk#Indonesia|crackers]], [[gudeg]] with [[rice]] wrapped in [[teak]] leaf, green [[Sambal|chili sambal]] and sliced [[Lime (fruit)|lime]].]] [[File:Nasi Tumpeng.jpg|thumb|200px|right|''Nasi [[tumpeng]]'', the quintessentially Javanese rice dish, symbolises the volcano.]] Javanese cuisine and culture place an important role in [[rice]], which is a staple food on the island. Among the Javanese it is considered not to be a meal if a person hasn't eaten rice yet.{{Cite book | last = Kalekin-Fishman | first = Devorah |author2=Kelvin E. Y. Low | title = Everyday Life in Asia: Social Perspectives on the Senses | publisher = Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. | year = 2010 | pages = 52 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=C7t7nSczT0YC | isbn = 978-0-7546-7994-3 | id = {{ISBN|0-7546-7994-2}} }} It is also important part of identity that differentiate Javanese with foreigners that eat [[bread]] (the Europeans) and resident of other island who eat [[sago]] (for example [[Molucca]]ns). Rice is also symbol of development and prosperity, while [[cassava]] and [[tuber]] is associated with poverty.{{Cite book | last = DuFon | first = Margaret A. |author2=Eton Churchill | title = Language learners in study abroad contexts | publisher = Multilingual Matters | year = 2006 | pages = 110 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nLOmNjjtz7oC | isbn = 978-1-85359-851-7 | id = {{ISBN|1-85359-851-8}} }} Javanese cuisine varies by region. Eastern Javanese cuisine has a preference for more salty and hot foods, while the Central Javanese prefer sweeter foods. A famous food in Javanese cuisine is [[Rujak#Rujak Cingur|''Rujak Cingur'']],{{Cite book | last = Tania | first = Vania | title = Djakabaia: Djalan-djalan dan Makan-makan | publisher = Gramedia Pustaka Utama | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=c33bzkrQ3vEC | isbn = 978-979-223923-2 | id = {{ISBN|979-22-3923-5}} }} marinated [[cow]] lips and noses served with vegetable, shrimp prawn and [[peanut sauce]] with [[Sambal|chili]]. Rojak Cingur is considered a traditional food in [[Surabaya]] in [[East Java]]. ''[[Gudeg]]'' is a traditional food from [[Yogyakarta]]{{Cite book | title = Tempat Makan Favorit di 6 Kota | publisher = AgroMedia | year = 2008 | pages = 136 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gtW1uy-sUr8C | isbn = 978-979-006166-8 | id = {{ISBN|979-006-166-8}} }} and [[Central Java]] which is made from young Nangka ([[jack fruit]]) boiled for several hours with [[palm sugar]], and [[coconut milk]]. ''[[Pecel]]'', a type of peanut sauce with chili{{Cite book | last = Witton | first = Patrick |author2=Mark Elliott |author3=Paul Greenway |author4=Virginia Jealous | title = Indonesia | publisher = Lonely Planet | year = 2003 | pages = 108 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=dmDYLxcPDPoC | isbn = 978-1-74059-154-6 | id = {{ISBN|1-74059-154-2}} }} is a common ingredient in Javanese cuisine. It is used in various types of [[Rujak]] and [[Gado-gado]]. It can also be used as stand-alone sauce with rice, prawns, eggs and vegetables as ''Nasi Pecel'' (Pecel rice).{{Cite book | last = Soebroto | first = Chris | title = Indonesia OK!!: the guide with a gentle twist | publisher = Galangpress Group | pages = 72 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mx9Wux2YJFsC&pg=PA72 | isbn = 978-979-934179-2 | id = {{ISBN|979-9341-79-5}} }} ''[[Tumpeng]]'', is a rice served in the shape of a [[stratovolcano|conical volcano]],{{Cite book | last = Kim | first = Hyung-Jun | title = Reformist Muslims in Yogyakarta Village: the Islamic transformation of contemporary socio-religious life | publisher = ANU E Press | year = 2006 | pages = 126 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xeC3CzdYDusC&pg=PA126 | isbn =978-1-920942-34-2 | id ={{ISBN|1-920942-34-3}} }} usually with rice coloured yellow using [[turmeric]]. It is an important part of many ceremonies in Java. Tumpeng is served at landmark events such as birthdays, moving house, or other ceremonies.{{Cite book | last = Owen | first = Sri | title = Indonesian Regional Food and Cookery | publisher = Frances Lincoln Ltd. | year = 1999 | pages = 173 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=r4yC_uDLnTQC&pg=PA173 | isbn =978-0-7112-1273-2 | id ={{ISBN|0-7112-1273-2}} }} Traditionally, Tumpeng is served alongside fried chicken, boiled egg, vegetables, and goat meat on a round plate made from [[bamboo]] called ''besek''. A notable food in Java is ''[[tempeh]]'', a [[meat substitute]] made from [[soy bean]] fermented with [[mould]]. It is a staple source of protein in Java and popular around the world as a meat substitute for [[vegetarian]]s. === Names === {{main article|Javanese names}} Javanese do not usually have family names or surnames, with only a single name. Javanese names may come from traditional Javanese languages, many of which are derived from [[Sanskrit]]. Names with the prefix ''Su-'', which means ''good'', are very popular. After the advent of Islam, many Javanese began to use [[Arabic]] names, especially coast populations, where Islamic influences are stronger. Commoners usually only have one-word names, while nobilities use two-or-more-word names, but rarely a surname. Some people use a [[patronymic]]. Due to the influence of other cultures, many people started using names from other languages, mainly [[European languages]]. [[Christian]] Javanese usually use [[Latin]] [[baptism]] names followed by a traditional Javanese name. ==Occupations== In Indonesia, Javanese people can be found in all occupations, especially in the government and the military. ===Farming=== Traditionally, most Javanese people are farmers. Farming is especially common because of the fertile volcanic soil in Java. The most important agricultural commodity is rice. In 1997, it was estimated that Java produced 55% of Indonesia's total output of the crop.{{Cite book | last = Gérard | first = Françoise |author2=François Ruf | title = Agriculture in crisis: people, commodities and natural resources in Indonesia, 1996-2000 | publisher = Routledge | year = 2001 | pages = 301 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2rj6kIpbb0UC&pg=PA301 | isbn = 978-0-7007-1465-0 | id = {{ISBN|0-7007-1465-0}} }} Most farmers work in small-scale rice fields, with around 42% of farmers working and cultivating less than 0.5 hectares of land. In region where soil is less fertile of where rainy season is short, other staple crops is cultivated, such as [[cassava]]. ===Blacksmith=== [[File:Semar Kris (alt) 3.jpg|thumb|A decorative kris with a figure of [[Semar]] as the handle. The ''bilah'' has thirteen ''luk''.]] Blacksmiths are traditionally valued. Some blacksmiths fast and meditate to reach perfection. Javanese blacksmiths create a range of tools and farming equipment, and also cultural items such as gamelan instruments and [[kris]].{{Cite book | last = Dunham | first = Stanley Ann | authorlink = Ann Dunham |author2=[[Alice G. Dewey]] | title = Surviving Against the Odds: Village Industry in Indonesia | publisher = Duke University Press | year = 2009 | pages = 50 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5WR76pKZzpYC&pg=PA50 | isbn = 978-0-8223-4687-6 | id = {{ISBN|0-8223-4687-7}} }} The [[Majapahit]] used fire-arms and cannonade as a feature of warfare. [[Cetbang]], the Javanese bronze breech-loaded swivel-gun, was used ubiquitously by the Majapahit navy, pirates, and rival lords. The demise of the [[Majapahit]] empire also caused the flight of disaffected skilled bronze cannon-smiths to [[Brunei]], modern [[Sumatra]] and [[Malaysia]], and the [[Philippines]]. This led to near universal use of the swivel-gun, especially on trade vessels to protect against pirates, in the [[Makassar Strait]].Thomas Stamford Raffles, ''The History of Java'', Oxford University Press, 1965, {{ISBN|0-19-580347-7}}, 1088 pages. [[Kris]] knives are important items, with many heirloom kris holding significant historical value. The design of the kris is to tear apart an opponent's abdomen, making the injury more severe. [[Kota Gede]] is famous for its [[silver]]works and silver handicrafts.{{Citation | author1=Tadié, J | author2=Guillaud, Dominique (ed.) | author3=Seysset, M. (ed.) | author4=Walter, Annie (ed.) | title=Kota Gede : le devenir identitaire d'un quartier périphérique historique de Yogyakarta (Indonésie); Le voyage inachevé... à Joël Bonnemaison | publication-date=1998 | publisher=ORSTOM | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/30808913 | accessdate=20 April 2012 }} ===Batik making=== [[Batik]]s are traditionally made by women as a pastime, but some town and villages have specialised in making batik, such as Pekalongan, Kauman, Kampung Taman and Laweyan. ===Wood carving=== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Houtsnijders vervaardigen maskers Nederlands-Indië TMnr 60026954.jpg|thumb|right|Javanese woodworkers making traditional masks during the [[Dutch East Indies]] era.]] The Javanese art of wood carving is traditionally applied to various cultural attributes such as statues, (wayang-)dolls, and masks. Woodcarving also prominent as house ornamentation and details. The elaborately carved Omah Kudus is a fine example of Javanese woodcarving mastery. The Central Java town of [[Jepara]] is famous as a center of Javanese woodcarving workshops, where artists and carpenters especially working on Javan [[teak]] wood.{{Cite news|url=https://forestsnews.cifor.org/53717/central-java-town-local-wood-enterprises-carve-niche-global-market?fnl=en|title=In a Central Java town, local wood enterprises carve a niche in the global market - CIFOR Forests News|date=2018-03-06|work=CIFOR Forests News|access-date=2018-06-01|language=en-US}} ==Migrations== The Javanese were probably involved in the Austronesian migration to [[Madagascar]] in the first centuries C.E. While the culture of the migration is most closely related with the [[Ma'anyan people]] of Borneo, a portion of the [[Malagasy language]] is derived from loanwords from the [[Javanese language]].{{Cite journal | last = Adelaar | first = Alexander | title = The Indonesian migrations to Madagascar: making sense of the multidisciplinary evidence | publisher = Melbourne Institute of Asian Languages and Societies, The [[University of Melbourne]] | year = 2006 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Szvr5hUtD5kC&pg=PA205 | isbn = 9789792624366 }} Since the Hindu kingdom period, Javanese [[merchant]]s settled at many places in the Indonesian archipelago.{{rp|247}} In the late 15th century, following the collapse of Majapahit and the rise of Muslim principalities on the northern coast of Java, many Hindu nobilities, artisans and courtiers migrated to [[Bali]],{{Cite book | last = Capaldi | first = Liz | authorlink = |author2=Joshua Eliot | title = Bali handbook with Lombok and the Eastern Isles: the travel guide | publisher = Footprint Travel Guides | year = 2000 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ZiHAw5zSHKkC | doi = | isbn = 978-0-658-01454-3 }} where they would contribute to the refined culture of Bali. Others who refused to convert to Islam retreated to [[Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park|Tengger mountain]], retaining their Hindu religion and becoming the [[Tenggerese people]]. In the conflicts during the transitions of power between the [[Sultanate of Demak|Demak]], the [[Kingdom of Pajang|Pajang]] and the [[Sultanate of Mataram|Mataram]] in the late 16th century, some Javanese migrated to [[Palembang]] in southern [[Sumatra]]. There they established a sultanate and formed a mix of [[Malay people|Malay]] and Javanese culture.{{Cite book | last = Simanjuntak | first = Truman |author2=Ingrid Harriet Eileen Pojoh |author3=Muhamad Hisyam | title = Austronesian diaspora and the ethnogeneses of people in Indonesian archipelago | publisher = Yayasan Obor Indonesia | year = 2006 | pages = 422 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Szvr5hUtD5kC | isbn = 978-979-26-2436-6 }} [[Palembang language]] is a dialect of [[Malay language]] with heavy influence of Javanese. During the reign of [[Sultan Agung of Mataram|Sultan Agung]] (1613–1645), some Javanese began to establish settlements in coastal [[West Java]] around [[Cirebon]], [[Indramayu]] and [[Karawang]]. These Javanese settlements were originally commissioned by Sultan Agung as rice farming villages to support the Javanese troop logistics on his military campaign against Dutch Batavia. The Javanese were also present in [[Peninsular Malaysia|Peninsular Malaya]] since early times.{{Cite book | last = Crawfurd | first = John | authorlink = John Crawfurd | title = A descriptive dictionary of the Indian islands & adjacent countries | publisher = Bradbury & Evans | year = 1856 | pages = 244 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gIZAAAAAYAAJ }} The Link between Java and Malacca was important during [[The spread of Islam in Indonesia|spread of Islam]] in Indonesia, when [[ulama|religious missionaries]] were sent from Malacca to seaports on the northern coast of Java. Large migrations to the Malay Peninsula occurred during the colonial period, mostly from Central Java to [[British Malaya]]. Migration also took place from 1880 to 1930 from other parts of Java with a secondary migration Javanese from Sumatra. Those migrations were to seek a new life away from the [[Dutch East Indies|Dutch colonists]] who ruled Indonesia at that time. Today these people live throughout Peninsular Malaysia and are mainly concentrated in parts of [[Johor]], [[Perak]] and [[Selangor]] and cities such as [[Kuala Lumpur]]. Today, the Javanese in Malaysia are included in [[Malay race]] along with other native Indonesian ethnics, it is estimated 40% of all Malays in Malaysia at least has some Javanese ancestry. {{Citation needed|date=July 2016}} In Singapore, approximately 50-60% of [[Malays in Singapore|its Malay population]] have some degree of Javanese ancestry. Most of them have identified themselves as Malays, rather than Javanese.{{cite book|last=LePoer|first=Barbara Leitch|title=Singapore, a country study|year=1991|publisher=Federal Research Division, [[Library of Congress]]|quote=Singapore Malay community leaders estimated that some 50 to 60 percent of the community traced their origins to Java and an additional 15 to 20 percent to Bawean Island, in the Java Sea north of the city of [[Surabaya]].|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=43QrSKQ0Q1EC|accessdate=17 February 2013|page=83}} Javanese merchants were also present in the [[Maluku Islands]] as part of the spice trade. Following the Islamisation of Java, they spread Islam in the islands, with [[Ternate]] being a Muslim sultanate circa 1484.{{Cite book | last = Storch | first = Tanya | title = Religions and missionaries around the Pacific, 1500-1900 | publisher = Ashgate Publishing | year = 2006 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rR0GbqNKDzAC | isbn = 978-0-7546-0667-3 }} Javanese merchants also converted coastal cities in [[Borneo]] to Islam.{{Cite book | last = Lapidus | first = Ira Marvin | title = A history of Islamic societies | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2002 | pages = 384 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=I3mVUEzm8xMC | isbn = 978-0-521-77933-3 }} The Javanese thus played an important part in transmitting Islam from the western part to the eastern part of [[List of islands of Indonesia|the Archipelago]] with trade based from northern coast of Java. [[File:Tropenmuseum Royal Tropical Institute Objectnumber 60006744 Javaanse arbeiders aangekomen bij de.jpg|thumb|Javanese migrant workers in Suriname, circa 1940.]] New migration patterns emerged during colonial periods. During the rise of [[Dutch East India Company|VOC]] power starting in the 17th century, many Javanese were exiled, enslaved or hired as mercenaries for the [[Dutch Empire|Dutch colonies]] of [[Ceylon]] in [[South Asia]] and the [[Cape colony]] in [[South Africa]]. These included princes and nobility who lost their dispute with the Company and were exiled along with their retinues. These, along with exiles from other ethnicities like [[Bugis]] and [[Malay people|Malay]] became the [[Sri Lankan Malay]] and [[Cape Malay]] ethnic groups respectively. Other political prisoners were transported to closer places. Prince [[Diponegoro]] and his followers were transported to [[North Sulawesi]], following his defeat in [[Java War]] in the early 19th century. Their descendants are well known as [[Jatons|Jaton]] (abbreviation of "Jawa Tondano"/Tondano Javanese). Major migrations started during the Dutch colonial period under [[Transmigration program]]s. The Dutch needed many labourers for their plantations and moved many Javanese under the program as contract workers, mostly to other parts of the colony in Sumatra. They also sent Javanese workers to [[Suriname]] in South America. Today approximately 15% of the Suriname population is of Javanese ancestry. The Transmigration program that was created by the Dutch continued following independence. A significant Javanese population can be found in the Jabodetabek ([[Greater Jakarta]]) area, [[Lampung]], [[South Sumatra]] and [[Jambi]] provinces. Several ''paguyuban'' (traditional community organisation) were formed by these Javanese immigrants, such as "Pujakesuma" (abbreviation of Indonesian: ''Putra Jawa Kelahiran Sumateran'' or Sumatra-born Javanese). == Notable people == {{main article|List of Javanese people}} ==See also== {{Portal|Indonesia}} * [[Javanese cuisine]] * [[Javanese literature]] * [[Javanese Kshatriya]] * [[Javanese Surinamese]] * [[Javanese Malaysian]] * [[Javanisation]] * [[Indonesians in Hong Kong]] * [[Indonesians in Saudi Arabia]] * [[Indonesians in Taiwan]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== {{refbegin}} * {{Citation | last =Caldarola | first =Carlo | year =1982 | title =Religion and Societies: Asia and the Middle East | publisher =Walter de Gruyter}} * {{Citation | last =Gin | first =Ooi Keat | year =2004 | title =Southeast Asia: A Historical Encyclopedia, from Angkor Wat to Timor. R-Z. Volume three | publisher =ABC-CLIO}} * {{Citation | last =Hooker | first =M.B. | year =1988 | title =Islam in South East Asia | publisher =Brill}} {{refend}} ==Further reading== * {{Citation | author1=Kuncaraningrat Raden Mas | author2=Southeast Asian Studies Program (Institute of Southeast Asian Studies) | title=Javanese culture | publication-date=1985 | publisher=Oxford University Press | isbn=978-0-19-582542-8 }} {{Commons category|Javanese}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Ethnic groups in Malaysia}} {{Ethnic groups in Singapore}} {{Ethnic groups in Suriname}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Malaysia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Singapore]] [[Category:Javanese people| ]] [[Category:Muslim communities of Indonesia]]
