{{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name= Sir Miles Dempsey |image= Lieutenant General M C Dempsey, Cb, Dso, Mc, Commander in Chief, British Second Army, April 1944 TR1654.jpg |image_size= 250px |caption= Lieutenant General Miles Dempsey in April 1944 |nickname= "Lucky"
"Bimbo"{{cite web|url=http://www.unithistories.com/officers/Army_officers_D02.html#Dempsey_MC|title=British Army officer histories|publisher=Unit Histories|accessdate=2017-06-28}} |birth_date= {{birth date|1896|12|15|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[New Brighton, Merseyside|New Brighton]], [[Wallasey|Wallasey, Cheshire]], England |death_date= {{death date and age|1969|6|6|1896|12|15|df=yes}} |death_place= [[Yattendon|Yattendon, Berkshire]], England |placeofburial= |allegiance= United Kingdom |branch= [[British Army]] |serviceyears= 1915–1947 |servicenumber= 9391 |rank= [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] |unit= [[Royal Berkshire Regiment]] |commands= [[Middle East Command|Middle East Land Forces]] (1946–47)
Allied Land Forces, South East Asia (1945–46)
[[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)|Fourteenth Army]] (1945)
[[Second Army (United Kingdom)|Second Army]] (1944–45)
[[XIII Corps (United Kingdom)|XIII Corps]] (1942–44)
[[42nd Armoured Division (United Kingdom)|42nd Armoured Division]] (1941–42)
[[42nd (East Lancashire) Infantry Division]] (1941)
[[46th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|46th Infantry Division]] (1941)
[[13th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|13th Infantry Brigade]] (1939–40)
1st Battalion, [[Royal Berkshire Regiment]] (1938–39) |battles= [[First World War]]
[[Second World War]]
[[Jewish insurgency in Mandatory Palestine|Palestine Emergency]] |awards= [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire]]{{London Gazette| issue=40669| supp=y| date=30 December 1955|page=6}}
[[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]]{{London Gazette| issue=36586| date=27 June 1944|page=3069|nolink=y}}
[[Distinguished Service Order]]
[[Military Cross]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (4){{London Gazette| issue=34904| supp=y| date=23 July 1940|page=4579|nolink=y}}{{London Gazette| issue=37213| supp=y| date=7 August 1945|page=4044|nolink=y}}{{London Gazette| issue=37521| supp=y| date=2 April 1946|page=1672|nolink=y}}
[[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Army Distinguished Service Medal]] (United States){{London Gazette| issue=38178| supp=y| date=13 January 1948|page=401|nolink=y}}
[[Legion of Merit|Commander of the Legion of Merit]] (United States){{London Gazette| issue=37027 |date=10 April 1945 |page=1947|supp=y |nolink=y}}
[[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|Grand Officer of the Order of Leopold with Palm]] (Belgium){{London Gazette| issue=37853| date=16 January 1947|page=324| supp=y|nolink=y}}
[[Croix de guerre (Belgium)|Croix de guerre with Palm]] (Belgium)
[[Order of Orange-Nassau|Knight Grand Officer of the Order of Orange-Nassau with Swords]] (Netherlands){{London Gazette| issue=37909| date=18 March 1947|page=1315| supp=y|nolink=y}} |relations= |laterwork= }} [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] '''Sir Miles Christopher Dempsey''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GBE|KCB|DSO|MC}} (15 December 1896 – 6 June 1969) was a senior [[British Army]] officer who served in both [[world war]]s. As a junior officer, he fought in France during the [[First World War]], where he was wounded, and served throughout the difficult [[interwar period]], travelling to various corners of the globe. During the [[Second World War]] he had a close relationship with [[Bernard Montgomery]] and commanded the [[13th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|13th Brigade]] in [[Battle of France|France]] in 1940, and spent the next two years training troops in England, before commanding [[XIII Corps (United Kingdom)|XIII Corps]] for the invasions of [[Allied invasion of Sicily|Sicily]] and [[Allied invasion of Italy|Italy]] in 1943. He later commanded the [[Second Army (United Kingdom)|Second Army]] during the [[Operation Overlord|Battle of Normandy]] and made rapid advances in the subsequent campaign in Northern France and Belgium and was the first British Army commander to cross the Rhine. A highly professional and dedicated career soldier who made his reputation in active service, Miles Dempsey was highly thought of by both his superiors and subordinates, most notably Montgomery, although he remains relatively unknown. ==Early life and military career== Miles Christopher Dempsey was born in [[Wallasey]], Cheshire on 15 December 1896.{{cite web|url=http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/2WWdempseyA.htm|title=Miles Dempsey biography at Spartacus Educational|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231085429/http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/2WWdempseyA.htm|archivedate=31 December 2013|df=dmy-all}} He is the descendant of a powerful clan in Offaly and Laois in Ireland with a very long history. His ancestor [[Terence O'Dempsey, 1st Viscount Clanmalier|Terence O'Dempsey, Viscount Clanmalier]], was loyal to the Catholic King James II and, as a result, lost all his lands in 1691. Dempsey's branch of the family then left Ireland for Cheshire.{{cite web|url=http://www.selectsurnames2.com/dempsey.html|title=the select surnames website|website=www.selectsurnames2.com|accessdate=3 May 2017}} The third and youngest son of Arthur Francis and Margaret Maud Dempsey, Miles Dempsey was educated at [[Shrewsbury School]], entering there in 1911, where he captained the first eleven [[Cricket]] team in 1914. On leaving Shrewsbury he attended the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] during the [[First World War]].Rostron 2010, pps. 1-2Smart, p. 81 During the [[First World War]] Dempsey, aged just 17, volunteered for the [[British Army]] and, after graduating from the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] in February 1915, six months after the outbreak of war, was [[Officer (armed forces)|commissioned]] as a [[second lieutenant]] into the [[Royal Berkshire Regiment]].Rostron 2010, p. 4-5{{London Gazette| issue=29292| date=10 September 1915|page=9066| supp=y|nolink=y}} Promoted to [[Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)|lieutenant]] in August 1915,Rostron 2010, p. 5{{London Gazette| issue=29489| date=25 February 1916|page=2101|nolink=y}} he served on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] with the 1st Battalion, Royal Berkshires, from June 1916 onwards. The battalion was a [[Standing army|Regular Army]] unit that, as part of the [[6th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|6th Brigade]] of the [[2nd Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|2nd Division]] (although by the time of Dempsey's arrival the battalion had been transferred to the [[99th Brigade (United Kingdom)|99th Brigade]] of the same division), had been one of the first units of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]] (BEF) to be sent overseas and was stationed in billets away from the [[Trench warfare|trenches]] in the [[Béthune]] sector.Rostron 2010, p. 6 Dempsey, serving as a [[Platoon|platoon commander]] in 'D' Company, first saw action during the [[Battle of Delville Wood]] in late July 1916, part of the larger [[Battle of the Somme|Somme offensive]]. The battalion, although successful in its role, had suffered heavy casualties, including 8 officers, and was relieved in the line and saw little further fighting throughout the year. Dempsey was promoted to [[Acting (rank)|acting]] [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] and assumed command of 'D' Company, and later 'B' Company. In November the battalion took part in an assault on Munich Trench, near the [[Serre (river)|River Serre]]. As at Delville Wood earlier in the year, the assault was successful but with heavy losses, although Dempsey again remained unscathed, and soon returned to England for home leave. In February 1917 he became the [[adjutant]] of the battalion.Rostron 2010, p. 10 Following attacks near [[Miraumont]] and then [[Oppy, Pas-de-Calais|Oppy]], during which Lance Corporal [[James Welch (VC)|James Welch]] was awarded the [[Victoria Cross]] (VC), the battalion, badly understrength, thereafter remained in a quiet sector of the front for most of the year, and was temporarily merged with the 23rd (Service) Battalion, [[Royal Fusiliers]]. Dempsey was soon posted as a [[Staff (military)|staff officer]] at [[II Corps (United Kingdom)|II Corps]] HQ, before returning to the 1st Royal Berkshires, this time in command of 'A' Company. In late November the battalion attacked Bourlon Wood as part of the [[Battle of Cambrai (1917)|Battle of Cambrai]].Rostron 2010, p. 11 On 12 March 1918, as the [[German Army (German Empire)|Germans]] prepared to launch their [[Spring Offensive]], they laid down a heavy [[Chemical weapons in World War I|mustard gas]] [[Barrage (artillery)|barrage]] on Dempsey's battalion, which was now at La Vacquerie with Dempsey commanding 'D' Company. Dempsey, along with 10 officers and 250 [[Other ranks (UK)|other ranks]], was wounded and later evacuated to England, where he had a lung removed.Rostron 2010, p. 12 Returning to the battalion in July, where, with the tide of the war having turned, the 1st Royal Berkshires took part in the [[Hundred Days Offensive]] until the war ended on [[Armistice of 11 November 1918|11 November 1918]]. By then the battalion was at [[Escarmain]].Rostron 2010, p. 13-14 Dempsey was awarded the [[Military Cross]] (MC), which was gazetted in the King's Birthday Honours list in June 1919.{{London Gazette| issue=31371| supp=y| date=30 May 1919|page=6826|nolink=y}} ==Between the wars== After the war, in 1919, Dempsey played two [[first-class cricket|first-class]] [[cricket]] matches for [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] against [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford University]] and [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]].{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/29/29036/First-Class_Matches.html|title=First-Class Matches played by Miles Dempsey|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=22 June 2012}} Between 1926 and 1932, he also played [[Minor Counties Championship]] cricket for [[Berkshire County Cricket Club|Berkshire]].{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/29/29036/Minor_Counties_Championship_Matches.html|title=Minor Counties Championship Matches played by Miles Dempsey|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=22 June 2012}} Dempsey returned to England with the 1st Royal Berkshires after it served in the [[Allied occupation of the Rhineland]], and later, with the battalion, was sent to [[Iraq]] in 1919, and later [[Persia]], the following year, where the battalion formed part of [[North Persia Force]] (or Norperforce).English, p. 52Rostron 2010, pps. 15-23 While his battalion was stationed in Persia, Dempsey took up [[Pelmanism (system)|Pelmanism]].Rostron 2010, p. 24 In late 1921 the battalion moved again, this time to [[Bareilly]], [[British Raj|India]], and Dempsey took over 'C' Company, but in 1922 returned to England for his first leave in almost three years, returning to India later in the year before returning to England again in 1923, this time to take up an appointment at the Royal Military College, Sandhurst. While there he commanded No. 1 Platoon of No. 1 Company, commanded by [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] [[Richard O'Connor]], who had served with distinction during the First World War, and later to serve with Dempsey again, under very different circumstances.Rostron 2010, pps. 25-28 Dempsey remained in this post, during which, in 1926, he was able to travel around Europe, until 1927, when he returned to regimental duties, returning to his regiment, although he was posted to the 2nd Battalion, then serving in Germany as part of the [[British Army of the Rhine]] (BAOR). Dempsey took over 'B' Company, and spent a large amount of his time travelling, mainly by bicycle, around Europe, visiting old battlefields of old wars, as well as likely scenes of battle in any future conflicts.Rostron 2010, pps. 28-29 In January 1930 Dempsey was admitted to the [[Staff College, Camberley]], graduating in December 1931.Smart, p. 82 His fellow students in the Junior Division included numerous future [[general officer]]s, including [[William Gott]], [[George F. Hopkinson|George Hopkinson]], [[James Steele (British Army officer)|James Steele]], [[George William Symes|George Symes]], [[Maurice Chilton]], [[Aubertin Walter Sothern Mallaby|Walter Mallaby]], [[Arthur Snelling (British Army officer)|Arthur Snelling]], [[Stuart Blundell Rawlins|Stuart Rawlins]], [[John Nichols (British Army officer)|John Nichols]] and [[Manley Angell James|Manley James]]. In the year senior to Dempsey, in the Senior Division attending from 1929–1930, included [[Neil Ritchie]], [[Herbert Lumsden]], [[George Erskine]], [[Ivor Hughes]], [[Reginald Denning]], [[Harold Redman]] and [[I. S. O. Playfair|Ian Playfair]], while in Dempsey's second year, the Junior Division, attending from 1931–1932, included [[Brian Horrocks]], [[Sidney Kirkman]], [[Frank Simpson (British Army officer)|Frank Simpson]], [[Joseph Baillon]], [[Arthur Dowler]], [[Thomas Wynford Rees|Thomas Rees]], [[Keith Arbuthnott, 15th Viscount of Arbuthnott|Keith Arbuthnott]] and [[Cameron Nicholson]]. The instructors in Dempsey's first year included [[Henry Maitland Wilson]], [[George Giffard]], [[Henry Willcox]], [[John George Walters Clark|John Clark]] and [[James Gammell]], and [[Arthur Percival]] and [[Sir John Smyth, 1st Baronet|John Smyth]].Rostron, pps. 30-31 Nearly all of these men were to achieve high rank in the upcoming war. Enjoying his time at the Staff College, Dempsey's first posting after Camberley was as a [[Staff (military)|General Staff Officer Grade 3]] (GSO3) to the [[Military Secretary (United Kingdom)|Military Secretary]], where he became responsible for the careers of all officers below the rank of [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|colonel]], having access to their annual confidential reports. Dempsey, by now a major (having been promoted in September 1932), held this post until late January 1934, when he handed over to Brian Horrocks upon receiving an appointment as [[brigade major]] of the [[5th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|5th Infantry Brigade]].Rostron 2010, pps. 34-35 The brigade, commanded by [[Brigadier (United Kingdom)|Brigadier]] [[Victor Fortune]] ([[Francis Nosworthy]] from 1935), formed part of the [[2nd Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|2nd Division]], then commanded by [[Major-general (United Kingdom)|Major General]] [[Archibald Wavell, 1st Earl Wavell|Archibald Wavell]], was serving in [[Aldershot Command]] and took part in numerous large-scale [[Military exercise|military maneouvres]] throughout Dempsey's time as brigade major and, after handing over again to Brian Horrocks in February 1936, he returned to the 1st Battalion of his regiment, taking command of HQ Company.Smart 2010, pps. 36-38 The battalion, then stationed in [[Shorncliffe, Kent]], was serving as part of the [[10th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|10th Brigade]] of the [[4th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|4th Division]], and shortly after Dempsey's return, the battalion was commanded by Lieutenant Colonel [[Eric Miles (British Army officer)|Eric Miles]].Rostron, p. 39 The following year Dempsey attended a brief course at the [[Senior Officers' School]] at [[Sheerness]], before being posted to South Africa, where he served as a GSO2 with the [[Union Defence Force (South Africa)|Defence Forces of the Union of South Africa]], a posting which he enjoyed. Relinquishing that post in late January 1938, he returned to England soon after to succeed Miles as [[Commanding Officer]] (CO) of the 1st Battalion, Royal Berkshires, and receiving a promotion to lieutenant colonel.Rostron 2010, p. 40 The battalion, still with the 10th Brigade, was both lacking in modern equipment and severely understrength, although, with the possibility of another war in Europe, the situation slowly changed and new equipment and reservists began arriving.Rostron, p. 40 ==Second World War== ===Belgium and France, 1939–1940=== [[File:British Generals 1939-1945 F3108.jpg|thumb|left|Brigadier Miles Dempsey and his staff, with their mascot 'Tiny' at Wervicq, France, pictured here in late 1939.]] By the start of the [[Second World War]] in September 1939 Dempsey's battalion had moved, transferring from Brigadier [[Evelyn Barker]]'s 10th Brigade to Brigadier [[Noel Irwin]]'s [[6th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|6th Brigade]], part of the 2nd Division, commanded by Major General [[Charles Loyd]]. Dempsey, with his battalion, was sent to France towards the end of the month, as part of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|British Expeditionary Force]] (BEF). In November he was promoted to the [[Acting (rank)|acting rank]] of brigadier and assumed command of the [[13th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|13th Infantry Brigade]] in place of Brigadier Henry Willcox, who had been one of Dempsey's instructors at the Staff College in the 1930s, which was already in France. Aged just 42, he was one of the youngest brigadiers in the British Army. The brigade formed part of Major General [[Harold Franklyn]]'s [[5th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|5th Division]], although by war's beginning the division was still not fully formed and so the brigade was sent to France as an independent formation two months before, and had spent most of its time on guard duties in the BEF's rear areas.Mead 2007, p. 117 The brigade, together with the [[15th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|15th Infantry Brigade]], under Brigadier [[Horatio Pettus Mackintosh Berney-Ficklin|Horatio Berney-Ficklin]], and the [[17th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|17th Infantry Brigade]], under Brigadier [[Montagu Stopford]], rejoined the 5th Division when the division HQ arrived in late December.Rostron 2010, pps. 42-43 In May 1940 the brigade saw action on the retreat from the River Dyle and then fought in the major defensive battle on the River Scarpe. When the Belgian Army surrendered in late May the brigade took part in the holding battle on the Ypres-Comines canal allowing Major General [[Bernard Montgomery]]'s [[3rd Division (United Kingdom)|3rd Infantry Division]] to cross their rear and secure the gap created by the Belgian collapse. In the subsequent [[Battle of Dunkirk|retreat to Dunkirk]] the brigade provided part of the rear-guard for the BEF during the [[Dunkirk evacuation]]. By the time the 13th Brigade returned to England it was reduced to a strength of less than 500 men, out of an original strength of nearly 3,000. For his services in France, Dempsey was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] in July 1940,{{London Gazette| issue=34893| supp=y| date=9 July 1940|page=4261|nolink=y}} which was presented to him personally by the GOC, Major General Franklyn, who was soon replaced by Major General Berney-Ficklin.Rostron 2010, p. 49 ===England, 1940–1942=== In July 1940 Dempsey took up the appointment of Brigadier General Staff (BGS) to the [[Canadian Corps (World War II)|Canadian Corps]] until June 1941 when he was appointed acting rank of major general to command of the [[46th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|46th Infantry Division]] and then [[42nd (East Lancashire) Infantry Division]] four months later, which was converting to an armoured division. requiring him to implement a huge training programme. Further challenges were presented in May 1942 when the establishment of British armoured divisions was altered to team an armoured brigade with an infantry brigade rather than two armoured brigades. By the end of the year Dempsey had become well-versed in the direction of combined armoured and infantry formations as well as an experienced trainer of troops.Mead 2007, p. 118 [[File:The Campaign in Sicily 1943 NA5687.jpg|thumb|right|Lieutenant General Dempsey with two of his staff (Major Priestly and Captain Hay) in Sicily, July 1943.]] ===North Africa, Sicily and Italy, 1942–1943=== In December 1942 Dempsey was promoted to [[Lieutenant-general (United Kingdom)|lieutenant general]] to command [[XIII Corps (United Kingdom)|XIII Corps]] of the [[Eighth Army (United Kingdom)|British Eighth Army]] in North Africa. Montgomery, the Eighth Army commander, had first spotted Dempsey's potential when he had been one of his students at the Staff College. On arrival in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]], Dempsey found his corps HQ in reserve because the long [[Line of communication|lines of communication]] to Eighth Army's spearhead could only sustain two corps ([[XXX Corps (United Kingdom)|XXX Corps]] and [[X Corps (United Kingdom)|X Corps]]). Dempsey was therefore employed in the planning of the [[Allied invasion of Sicily|invasion of Sicily]] and led his corps in the assault on Sicily in July 1943. The invasion was spearheaded by [[airborne forces]] under Dempsey's command (see operations [[Operation Ladbroke|Ladbroke]] and [[Operation Fustian|Fustian]]).Rostron 2010, pps. 62-65 In early August Dempsey relieved Major General [[Horatio Pettus Mackintosh Berney-Ficklin|Horatio Berney-Ficklin]], commander of the [[5th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|5th Infantry Division]], then under XIII Corps.Rostron 2010, p. 66 Towards the end of the campaign, Dempsey's HQ was withdrawn to reserve to plan [[Operation Baytown]], Eighth Army's part in the [[Allied invasion of Italy|invasion of Italy]] across the [[Strait of Messina]].Mead 2007, p. 119 Although his Corps' landing on 3 September was unopposed, the Germans ensured his progress was slow by destroying bridges and culverts on the only routes through the harsh terrain. It took nearly two weeks to advance more than {{convert|300|mi|km}} to the north to link up with the [[United States Army North|U.S. Fifth Army]] (which contained, in addition to the [[VI Corps (United States)|U.S. VI Corps]], the British X Corps) landing at Salerno as part of [[Allied invasion of Italy#Salerno landings|Operation Avalanche]]. Allied forces then commenced to fight their way northward with Fifth Army to the west and Eighth Army to the east of Italy's [[Apennine Mountains|Apennine Mountain]] spine. The corps later took part in the [[Moro River Campaign]] but the severe winter weather forbade any further progress. [[File:Lieutenant General M C Dempsey, Cb, Dso, Mc, Commander in Chief, British Second Army, April 1944 TR1655.jpg|thumb|left|Half length portrait of Lieutenant General Sir Miles Dempsey taken at his desk, April 1944.]] ===Northwestern Europe, 1944–1945=== In North Africa, Sicily and Italy, Montgomery's faith in Dempsey had proved justified and he had also gained a reputation for his expertise in [[Combined Operations]]. This prompted Montgomery, when he left Italy at the end of 1943 to take command of the [[21st Army Group]] for the forthcoming [[Normandy landings|D-Day landings]], to select Dempsey to command the [[Second Army (United Kingdom)|British Second Army]]. The Second Army was the main British force (although it also included [[Canadian Army]] units) involved in the landings, making successful assaults at [[Gold Beach|Gold]], [[Juno Beach|Juno]] and [[Sword Beach|Sword]] beaches on 6 June 1944. [[File:Bradley - Montgomery - Dempsey.jpg|thumb|right|Lieutenant General Sir M.C. Dempsey (right) with the [[21st Army Group]] commander, [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] [[Bernard Montgomery|Sir Bernard Montgomery]] (centre), and [[First United States Army|U.S. First Army]] commander, [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] [[Omar Bradley]] (left), 10 June 1944.]] The successful assaults were followed by a [[Attrition warfare|battle of attrition]] during which the Anglo-Canadian forces were frustrated by determined German resistance. This fighting drew vital German units including the bulk of their armoured strength to the [[Caen]] sector, facilitating the breakout further west in July (see [[Operation Cobra]]) by [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] [[George S. Patton]]'s [[United States Army Central|U.S. Third Army]].Mead 2007, p. 120 The Second Army then made a rapid advance across northern France into [[Belgium]], liberating [[Brussels]] and [[Antwerp]] in September 1944. On 15 October 1944, during a visit to the Second Army, [[George VI|King George VI]] [[knight]]ed Dempsey on the battlefield. Because of the fast and successful advance over more than 200 miles in a week Dempsey received the nickname of "Two Hundred Miles" Dempsey. Second Army's XXX Corps (now commanded by Lieutenant General [[Brian Horrocks]]) took part in [[Operation Market Garden]], the failed attempt to secure an early crossing of the River Rhine in September 1944, which Dempsey believed could not succeed and openly questioned to Montgomery. Airborne troops secured a succession of canal and river crossings to enable XXX Corps to reach the Lower Rhine at [[Arnhem]] and wheel right into Germany. Intelligence had not detected the presence of unexpected German formations in the area and resistance proved greater than expected frustrating XXX Corps attempts to reach its final objective. During the operation, Dempsey, forward near the front with his Tac HQ, witnessed the crossing of the [[82nd Airborne Division|U.S. 82nd Airborne Division]]'s [[504th Infantry Regiment (United States)|504th Parachute Regiment]] cross the [[Nijmegen]] bridge. Impressed, he later wrote that the 82nd was "easily the best division on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western front]]".Rostron 2010, p. 143 Dempsey met with the 82nd's commander, [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[James M. Gavin]], shook him by the hand and said "I am proud to meet the commander of the greatest division in the world today."Rostron 2010, p. 141 [[File:General Dempsey crossing the Rhine.jpg|thumb|left|Lieutenant General Dempsey crossing the [[Rhine]] in a small boat, March 1945.]] The Second Army, with XII and XXX Corps in the vanguard and [[II Canadian Corps]] under command and [[VIII Corps (United Kingdom)|VIII Corps]] in reserve eventually [[Operation Plunder|crossed the Rhine]] on 23 March 1945,Mead 2007, pp. 120–121 and Dempsey was the first British Army commander to do so. On 7 April 1945, ''[[The Illustrated London News]]'' carried a full front page of a specially commissioned portrait painting of Dempsey by artist [[Arthur Pan]].[http://www.iln.org.uk/iln_years/year/1945.htm "The Illustrated London News 1945"], iln.org.uk. Retrieved 19 September 2009. In May, Dempsey's men captured [[Bremen (city)|Bremen]], Hamburg and [[Kiel]]. At 11.00 am on 3 May, a delegation of senior German officers led by General Admiral [[Hans-Georg von Friedeburg|von Friedeberg]] arrived at Dempsey's Tac HQ and after questioning it appeared that Friedeberg was a representative of ''[[Generalfeldmarschall]]'' [[Wilhelm Keitel|Keitel]] and Grand Admiral [[Karl Dönitz|Dönitz]] who wished to surrender. In typical fashion Dempsey sent them on their way to report to Montgomery which led to the [[German surrender at Lüneburg Heath|formal surrender]] the next day at Lüneberg Heath. ===Far East, 1945–1946=== After the [[end of World War II in Europe]], Dempsey was appointed to the command of the [[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)|British Fourteenth Army]] and GOC in C [[Malaya Command]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gulabin.com/armynavy/pdf/Army%20Commands%201900-2011.pdf |title=Army Commands |publisher= |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705211343/http://www.gulabin.com/armynavy/pdf/Army%20Commands%201900-2011.pdf |archivedate=5 July 2015 |df= }} and then Land Force Commander, South East Asia. By the time he had arrived however, the war in the East was also over.Mead 2007, p. 121 Within his command were 123,000 British and Dutch prisoners and nearly 750,000 captured Japanese. Miles Dempsey, although modest and unassuming, was considered to be a highly competent officer. He asserted a very effective control over the [[British Second Army|Second Army (United Kingdom)]] without taking the limelight. This was despite the stalemate in Normandy and the failure to advance beyond Antwerp and thus ensure that German forces remained isolated. He was claimed by military historian [[Carlo D'Este]] to be: {{quote|A career infantryman, Dempsey was an ardent student of military history and during the interwar period had frequently visited Europe to study its battlefields firsthand. Blessed with an active and incisive mind, a phenomenal memory and a unique skill in reading maps, Dempsey would soon leave his army staff in awe over his ability to remember everything he saw on a map, to bring a landscape literally to life in his mind even though he had never actually seen it. This talent proved particularly important during the crucial [[Battle for Caen|battles around Caen]] in June and July 1944. Dempsey was considered the Eighth Army's best expert in [[combined operations]] and, as he grew in experience, Montgomery soon recognized his potential for army command. The two men shared many qualities, including a disdain for paperwork and a determination, based on their First World War experiences, never to waste their soldiers lives.D'Este 2004, p. 60.}} ==Post-war== In 1946 he was appointed [[Commander-in-Chief]] (C-in-C) of [[Middle East Command|Middle East Land Forces]], and was in command throughout the [[Jewish insurgency in Mandatory Palestine|Palestine Emergency]]. He was made acting general in June 1946{{London Gazette| issue=37648| supp=y| date=9 July 1946|page=3607|nolink=y}} which was made permanent in October 1946{{London Gazette| issue=37764| supp=y| date=18 October 1946|page=5191|nolink=y}} and was appointed to the ceremonial post of Aide de Camp general to the King.{{London Gazette| issue=37781| supp=y| date=5 November 1946|page=5461|nolink=y}} Dempsey retired from the British Army in August 1947.{{London Gazette|issue=38051|date=19 August 1947|page=3933|supp=y|nolink=y}} In 1950, he was given a 'shadow' appointment as Commander In Chief, British Home forces which he relinquished in 1956.{{London Gazette| issue=40698| supp=y| date=27 January 1956|page=639|nolink=y}} He held the ceremonial posts of [[Colonel Commandant]] of the [[Royal Military Police]], (1947 to 1957){{London Gazette| issue=37990| supp=y| date=17 June 1947|page=2772|nolink=y}}{{London Gazette| issue=41034| supp=y| date=26 March 1957|page=6169|nolink=y}} as well as the [[Special Air Service]] (1951–1960){{London Gazette| issue=39176| supp=y| date=16 March 1951|page=1498|nolink=y}}{{London Gazette| issue=42004| supp=y| date=8 April 1960|page=2640|nolink=y}} and [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|Colonel of the Regiment]] of the [[Royal Berkshire Regiment|Princess Charlotte of Wales Royal Berkshire Regiment]] (1946 to 1956).{{London Gazette| issue=37823| supp=y| date=17 December 1946|page=6169|nolink=y}}{{London Gazette| issue=40928| supp=y| date=16 November 1946|page=6564|nolink=y}} He was also [[Honorary Colonel]] of the [[Army Reserve (United Kingdom)|Territorial army's]] 21st SAS Regiment (Artists Rifles) from 1948 to 1951.{{London Gazette |issue=38237 |supp=2 |date=12 March 1948 |page=1866 |nolink=y}}{{London Gazette| issue=39270| supp=y| date=26 June 1951|page=3538|nolink=y}} In 1948, Dempsey married Viola O'Reilly, the youngest daughter of Captain [[Percy O'Reilly]] of [[Coolamber]], [[County Westmeath]], Ireland. The couple lived at "The Old Vicarage", Greenham, [[Newbury, Berkshire]], and later rented "Coombe House", Yattendon, Berkshire. When the former house was requisitioned as part of the U.S. Airforce base, President Eisenhower personally arranged compensation to be paid to his friend and wartime colleague.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} He was Chairman of the Race Course Betting Board, [[Simonds Brewery|H&G Simonds]], [[Greene King|Greene King and Sons]] (the first non-family chairman) and Deputy Chairman of [[Courage Brewery|Courage Ltd]]. He was commissioned as a Deputy Lord Lieutenant in the county of Berkshire in 1950.{{London Gazette| issue=39053| date=27 October 1950|page=5362|nolink=y}} Dempsey declined to write any memoirs about his military experiences. He ordered that his diaries be burned.{{cite book|title=Master of the Battlefield Monty's War Years 1942–1944|last1=Hamilton|first1=Nigel|publisher=McGraw-Hill Book Company|year=1983|page=697}} ==Death== After returning to England from visiting a nephew in [[Kenya]], Dempsey was diagnosed with cancer. He died soon afterwards, on 6 June 1969, at the age of 72, exactly 25 years after [[Normandy landings|D-Day]]. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=djft3U1LymYC&dat=19690606&printsec=frontpage&hl=en "D-Day General Dies", ''Pittsburgh Press'', June 6, 1969, p1 "Obituary— General Sir Miles Dempsey", ''The Guardian'', June 7, 1969, p3 He is buried at [[Yattendon]] churchyard, [[Berkshire]].Rostron 2010, p. 200 ==Tributes== * In September 1944, Sir Miles Dempsey was made an honorary citizen of the city of [[Caen]] in Normandy, France. * Around 1990, a street in Caen (''avenue Général Dempsey'') was named after him,Caen map, La Poste, 1993. in a district close to the [[Mémorial pour la Paix museum]], where many of the streets commemorate personalities linked with the Second World War. The street links the ''avenue Maréchal Montgomery'' to the ''avenue Amiral Mountbatten''. * In the Dutch town of [[Langenboom]] a street was named after him (''Dempseystraat''). * In the small Belgian town of [[Hamont-Achel]], General Sir Miles Dempsey and his Second Army held their headquarters here, from September 1944 until April 1945. In honour, the street was named after him ''Generaal Dempseylaan''. * In Singapore, Dempsey Hill and Dempsey Road are named after him.{{cite web|url=http://www.dempseyhill.com/history.html|title=Dempsey|website=www.dempseyhill.com|accessdate=3 May 2017}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book |first=Carlo |last=D'Este |authorlink=Carlo D'Este |title=Decision in Normandy: The Real Story of Montgomery and the Allied Campaign |location=London |publisher=Penguin |year=2004 |origyear=1983 |isbn=0-14-101761-9 |oclc=44772546| ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=English|first=John|title=Patton's Peers: The Forgotten Allied Field Army Commanders of the Western Front, 1944–45|year=2009|publisher=Stackpole Books|location=|isbn=978-0-8117-0501-1}} * {{cite book| first=Richard| last=Mead| title=Churchill's Lions| year=2007| publisher=Spellmount| location=Stroud, Gloucestershire|isbn=978-1-86227-431-0 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book| first=Peter| last=Rostron| title=The Military life and times of General Sir Miles Dempsey, Monty's Army Commander| year=2010| publisher=Pen & Sword Military| location=South Yorkshire (England)| isbn=9781844684885 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book| first=Nick| last=Smart| title=Biographical Dictionary of British Generals of the Second World War| isbn=1844150496| year=2005| location=Barnesley| publisher=Pen & Sword}} ==External links== *[http://www.unithistories.com/officers/Army_officers_D02.html#Dempsey_MC British Army Officers 1939−1945] *[http://www.generals.dk/general/Dempsey/Sir_Miles_Christopher/Great_Britain.html Generals of World War II] {{Commons category|Miles Dempsey}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Douglas Wimberley]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[46th Infantry Division (United Kingdom)|GOC 46th Infantry Division]]|years=June–October 1941}} {{s-aft|after=[[Harold Freeman-Attwood]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Eric Miles]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[42nd (East Lancashire) Infantry Division|GOC 42nd (East Lancashire) Infantry Division]]|years=October–November 1941}} {{s-non|reason=Post redesignated ''42nd Armoured Division''}} |- {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=[[42nd Armoured Division (United Kingdom)|GOC 42nd Armoured Division]]|years=1941–1942}} {{s-aft|after=[[John Aldam Aizlewood|John Aizlewood]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Brian Horrocks]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[XIII Corps (United Kingdom)|GOC XIII Corps]]|years=1942–1943}} {{s-aft|after=[[Sidney Kirkman]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Kenneth Arthur Noel Anderson|Kenneth Anderson]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Second Army (United Kingdom)|GOC Second Army]]|years=1944–1945}} {{s-non|reason=Post disbanded}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[William Slim, 1st Viscount Slim|Sir William Slim]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)|GOC Fourteenth Army]]|years=July–November 1945}} {{s-non|reason=Post disbanded}} |- {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Malaya Command|GOC Malaya Command]]|years=November – December 1945}} {{s-aft|after=[[Frank Messervy|Sir Frank Messervy]]}} |- {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Middle East Command|C-in-C Middle East Land Forces]]|years=1946–1947}} {{s-aft|after=[[John Crocker|Sir John Crocker]]}} |- {{s-hon}} {{s-bef|before=[[Robert Collins (British Army officer)|Robert Collins]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Royal Berkshire Regiment|Colonel of the Royal Berkshire Regiment]]|years=1946–1956}} {{s-aft|after=[[Dudley William Bruce Trower Hogg|Dudley Hogg]]}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dempsey, Miles}} stood again for General Secretary of the Labour Party
revision.text:
[[File:Paul Hilder-108 (cropped).png|thumb|upright|Paul Hilder in 2014]] '''Paul Hilder''' is a British-born social entrepreneur, writer and organiser. He is co-founder and Chief International Officer of [[Crowdpac]], the platform for new politics, where he works with [[Steve Hilton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.crowdpac.co.uk/about/team|title=Crowdpac - Giving politics back to people|website=Crowdpac.co.uk|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref> In 2000 he co-founded [[openDemocracy.net]], a website for debate about global politics and culture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/content/articles/PDF/Interview_Barnett.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029061454/http://www.opendemocracy.net/content/articles/PDF/Interview_Barnett.pdf |archivedate=2008-10-29 |df= }} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/article/globalisation/visions_reflections/happy_birthday_anthony_barnett#nine|title=Anthony Barnett: a radical’s fanfare|website=Opendemocracy.net|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref> He helped launch the global web movement [[Avaaz.org]] in 2007, and served as one of its first campaign directors.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://personaldemocracy.com/content/avaazorg-moveon-goes-international |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715071016/http://personaldemocracy.com/content/avaazorg-moveon-goes-international |archivedate=2011-07-15 |df= }} </ref> In 2010, he became Director of Campaigns for [[Oxfam]], the global development movement. In 2012, he became Vice President of Global Campaigns at [[Change.org]].
In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]] Hilder was campaign director for Vote4Peace.org.uk which sought to support 40 anti-[[2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq war]] MPs in marginal seats, and to help elect Liberal Democrats standing in Conservative marginal seats.<ref name=guardian-20050221>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/feb/21/politics.election2005 |title=£100,000 defence fund for anti-war MPs |author=Daphna Baram, David Hencke |newspaper=The Guardian |date=21 February 2005 |accessdate=13 March 2018}}</ref>
Hilder previously stood as a self-declared "outsider" candidate for the role of [General Secretary of the Labour Party|General Secretary] of the [[Labour Party (UK)|UK Labour Party]] in 2011, and was described at the time as a "strong candidate".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://labourlist.org/2011/07/labours-next-general-secretary-time-for-transparency/|title=Labour's next General Secretary: Time for transparency - LabourList|date=7 July 2011|website=Labourlist.org|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref> In a [[New Statesman]] article in 2014, he wrote that his candidacy for the role had centred on "movement politics and democratic renewal".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2014/11/new-politics-how-old-political-consensus-melting-away|title=A new politics? How the old political consensus is melting away|website=Newstatesman.com|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref> In the same piece, Hilder reported on [[Douglas Carswell]]'s successful 2014 by-election campaign after switching from the Conservatives to UKIP and on the Scottish referendum campaign, and on the subject of "new politics" through conversations with figures such as [[Jon Cruddas]], [[Rory Stewart]], [[Lisa Nandy]], [[Stewart Wood, Baron Wood of Anfield|Stewart Wood]] and [[Maurice Glasman]]. Hilder argued that "over the coming months and years, this new politics will shake the British establishment to its foundations. It has many faces but a common origin: the growing consensus that the status quo is broken and old politics is actively disempowering".
In March 2016 he called for the establishment of an English Labour Party, writing that "the Labour Party will never again win a UK parliamentary majority unless it can transform its relationship with English voters."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://labourlist.org/2016/03/seven-steps-for-labour-to-win-england/|title=Seven steps for Labour to win England - LabourList|date=14 March 2016|website=Labourlist.org|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref>
Also in March 2016, Hilder travelled around the US with the [[Bernie Sanders]] campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. In The Guardian, he described the campaign as "a political start-up growing exponentially in a cauldron of American discontent".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/mar/12/inside-bernie-sanders-campaign-do-or-die|title=It's not over til it's over: inside the Sanders campaign's do-or-die moment|first=Paul|last=Hilder|date=12 March 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> He interviewed [[Zack Exley]] and other organizers of the campaign about their volunteer-driven approach, writing that "The Bernie campaign is working toward a political revolution" and that their digital infrastructure was "fast growing into something more powerful even than the Obama campaign". Elsewhere, he argued that the Sanders movement was "changing the laws of political physics" and that "in the most important sense, he has already won".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rawstory.com/2016/03/the-momentum-story-how-the-bernie-sanders-crowd-can-still-win/|title=The momentum story: How the Bernie Sanders crowd can still win|date=3 March 2016|website=Rawstory.com|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref>
According to [[Politico]], Hilder has been "cited as an inspiration by some of the leading figures in Momentum for his work on political campaigning".<ref>{{cite news|last1=McTague|first1=Tom|title=Jeremy Corbyn copies the Bernie Sanders playbook|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/jeremy-corbyn-labour-leader-copies-the-bernie-sanders-playbook-socialist-campaign-momentum/|accessdate=2 March 2018|publisher=Politico|date=15 August 2016}}</ref> He also appeared on The Daily Politics as a Momentum member, speaking supportively about the membership vote that shifted that movement toward a more participatory model of democracy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Daily Politics|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b088s1qq|accessdate=2 March 2018|publisher=BBC|date=13 January 2017}}</ref>
In a long [[Prospect Magazine]] essay in April 2017, Hilder drew on experiences "behind the scenes with winning insurgent campaigns" to make an argument that 2016 was "the West's 1989", comparing the campaigns for Donald Trump, Brexit and Bernie Sanders.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hilder|first1=Paul|title=The new politics: the revolution will be digitised|journal=Prospect Magazine|date=7 April 2017|url=https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/the-new-politics-the-revolution-will-be-digitised|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref>
In 2018 Hilder stood again for [[General Secretary of the Labour Party]], but was not short-listed.<ref name=newstatesman-20180308>{{cite news |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/staggers/2018/03/paul-hilder-labour-general-secretary-NEC |title=Why I am the right person to turn Labour into a 21st century movement |last=Hilder |first=Paul |newspaper=New Statesman |date=8 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref><ref name=labourlist-20180315>{{cite news |url=https://labourlist.org/2018/03/jennie-formby-and-christine-blower-shortlisted-for-general-secretary-post/ |title=Jennie Formby and Christine Blower shortlisted for general secretary post |last=Rodgers |first=Sienna |website=Labourlist |date=15 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
Hilder was involved in the launch of the British campaigning movement [[38 Degrees]], and served as one of its board members. In 2010 he gave a [[TED (conference)|TED]]x talk on "The Power of Food", linked to the 2010 UN Millennium Development Goals summit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S9UigzXGpNo|title=TEDx London - Paul Hilder|date=23 November 2010|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref> He is a trustee of the Article 1 Charitable Trust, which was founded in 2004 to lobby on issues related to [[Sudan]] and [[Darfur]].<ref name=article1-who>{{cite web |url=http://www.article1.org/ |title=Article 1 - Who We Are |publisher=Article 1 |accessdate=13 March 2018}}</ref>
==Publications== He is the author or editor of several works, including: * (2007) Contentious Citizens (Carnegie / Young Foundation)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.youngfoundation.org/publications/reports/contentious-citizens-civil-societys-role-campaigning-social-change-may-2007 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707031619/http://www.youngfoundation.org/publications/reports/contentious-citizens-civil-societys-role-campaigning-social-change-may-2007 |archivedate=2010-07-07 |df= }} </ref> * (2005) Iraqi Liberation ([[Oxford Research Group]]) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordresearchgroup.org.uk/sites/default/files/iraqiliberation.pdf|format=PDF|title=IRAQI LIBERATION?|website=Oxfordresearchgroup.org.uk|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref> * (2005) "Open Parties? A map of 21st century democracy" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/democracy-open_politics/article_2312.jsp|title=Open parties? A map of 21st century democracy|website=Opendemocracy.net|accessdate=2017-08-09}}</ref> * (2005) "Move On, World" (Fabian Review)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.youngfoundation.org/publications/articles/move-world-march-2005 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727034645/http://www.youngfoundation.org/publications/articles/move-world-march-2005 |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }} </ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hilder, Paul}} [[Category:Social entrepreneurs]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Paulo Sérgio Licciardi Messeder Barreto | image = | image_size = 150px | caption = Paulo Barreto in 2005 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|11|19|df=y}} | birth_place = {{flagicon|Brazil}} [[Salvador, Bahia]], Brazil | residence = {{flagicon|United States}} [[Tacoma, Washington]], U.S.A. | alma_mater = [[University of São Paulo]] | known_for = [[Cryptographic hash functions]], [[Pairing-based cryptography]], [[Post-quantum cryptography]] | website = http://directory.tacoma.uw.edu/employee/pbarreto | work_institution = [[Polytechnic School of the University of São Paulo|Escola Politécnica]], [[University of São Paulo]] [[University of Washington Tacoma|Institute of Technology, University of Washington Tacoma]] }}
'''Paulo S. L. M. Barreto''' (born 1965) is a [[Brazil]]ian [[cryptographer]] and one of the designers of the [[Whirlpool (algorithm)|Whirlpool]] [[cryptographic hash function|hash function]] and the [[block cipher]]s [[Anubis (cipher)|Anubis]] and [[KHAZAD]], together with [[Vincent Rijmen]]. He has also co-authored a number of research works on [[elliptic curve cryptography]] and [[pairing-based cryptography]], including the [[eta pairing]] technique,<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10623-006-9033-6 |title=Efficient pairing computation on supersingular Abelian varieties |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 |doi=10.1007/s10623-006-9033-6 |journal=Designs, Codes and Cryptography |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=239–271 |year=2007 |last1=Barreto |first1=Paulo S. L. M. |last2=Galbraith |first2=Steven D. |last3=Ó'hÉigeartaigh |first3=Colm |last4=Scott |first4=Mike |issn=0925-1022 }}</ref> [[identity-based cryptography|identity-based cryptographic]] protocols,<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/11593447_28 |title=Efficient and Provably-Secure Identity-Based Signatures and Signcryption from Bilinear Maps |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 |doi=10.1007/11593447_28 |journal=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |volume=3788 |pages=515–532 |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |year=2005 |last1=Barreto |first1=Paulo S. L. M. |last2=Libert |first2=Benoît |last3=McCullagh |first3=Noel |last4=Quisquater |first4=Jean-Jacques |isbn=978-3-540-30684-9 }}</ref> and the family of [[Barreto-Naehrig curves|Barreto-Naehrig (BN)]] pairing-friendly [[elliptic curve cryptography|elliptic curve]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/11693383_22 |title=Pairing-Friendly Elliptic Curves of Prime Order |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 |doi=10.1007/11693383_22 |journal=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |volume=3897 |pages=319–331 |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |year=2006 |last1=Barreto |first1=Paulo S. L. M. |last2=Naehrig |first2=Michael |isbn=978-3-540-33108-7 }}</ref> More recently he has been focusing his research on [[post-quantum cryptography]], being one of the discoverers of [[quasi-dyadic codes]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-05445-7_24 |title=Compact McEliece Keys from Goppa Codes |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-05445-7_24 |journal=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |volume=5867 |pages=376–392 |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |year=2009 |last1=Barreto |first1=Paulo S. L. M. |last2=Misoczki |first2=Rafael |isbn=978-3-642-05443-3 }}</ref> and [[quasi-cyclic moderate-density parity-check (QC-MDPC) codes]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6620590/?reload=true&tp=&arnumber=6620590 |title=MDPC-McEliece: New McEliece variants from Moderate Density Parity-Check codes |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 |doi=10.1109/ISIT.2013.6620590 |journal=Proceedings of the 2013 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT 2013) |volume= |pages= |year=2013 |last1=Misoczki |first1=Rafael |last2=Tillich |first2=Jean-Pierre |last3=Sendrier |first3=Nicolas |last4=Barreto |first4=Paulo S. L. M. |isbn=978-1-4799-0446-4 }}</ref> to instantiate the [[McEliece cryptosystem|McEliece]] and [[Niederreiter cryptosystem|Niederreiter]] cryptosystems and related schemes.
His paper "Efficient Algorithms for Pairing-Based Cryptosystems",<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/3-540-45708-9_23 |title=Efficient Algorithms for Pairing-Based Cryptosystems |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 |doi=10.1007/3-540-45708-9_23 |journal=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |volume=2442 |pages=354–369 |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |year=2002 |last1=Barreto |first1=Paulo S. L. M. |last2=Kim |first2=Hae Y. |last3=Lynn |first3=Ben |last4=Scott |first4=Mike |isbn=978-3-540-44050-5 }}</ref> jointly written with Hae Y. Kim, Ben Lynn and Mike Scott and presented at the [[CRYPTO (conference)|Crypto]] 2002 conference, has been identified in March 2005 as a "Hot Paper", and in December 2005 as "Fast Breaking Paper", by [[Thomson ISI]]'s Essential Science Indicators (now Science Watch), by virtue of being among the top one-tenth of one percent (0.1%) most cited papers and by having the largest percentage increase in citations in the Computer Science category.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nancy Imelda Schafer, ISI |url=http://www.esi-topics.com/nhp/2005/march-05-PauloBarreto.html |title=New Hot Paper Comment by Paulo S.L.M. Barreto |publisher=Esi-topics.com |date=2005-12-01 |accessdate=2017-09-09 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Nancy Imelda Schafer, ISI |url=http://www.esi-topics.com/fbp/fbp-december2005.html |title=Fast Breaking Papers - December 2005 |publisher=Esi-topics.com |date= |accessdate=2017-09-09 }}</ref>
Barreto was born in [[Salvador, Brazil|Salvador]], capital of the northeastern state of [[Bahia]], [[Brazil]]. In 1987, he graduated in Physics at the [[University of São Paulo]]. He subsequently worked at [[Unisys Brazil Ltd]] and [[Scopus Tecnologia S/A]] as a software developer and then as chief cryptographer. Barreto received his [[PhD|Ph.D.]] degree in 2003. He has been awarded the [[Science Foundation Ireland|SFI]] E. T. S. Walton Award 2008-2009. He was associate professor at the Department of Computer and Digital Systems Engineering, [[Polytechnic School of the University of São Paulo|Escola Politécnica]], [[University of São Paulo]]. He is currently a professor at the [[University of Washington Tacoma|Institute of Technology of the University of Washington Tacoma]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://directory.tacoma.uw.edu/employee/pbarreto|title=pbarreto {{!}} Faculty & Staff Directory|website=directory.tacoma.uw.edu|access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cwds.uw.edu/users/pbarreto|title=pbarreto {{!}} Center for Data Science|website=cwds.uw.edu|access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official Website|http://www.larc.usp.br/members/paulo-sergio-licciardi-messeder-barreto/}} at the [[University of São Paulo]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barreto, Paulo}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Modern cryptographers]] [[Category:University of Washington faculty]] [[Category:University of São Paulo alumni]] [[Category:Brazilian expatriate academics in the United States]]
